description:
Love this place, finally got to try this place out this past Saturday after an hour at Spin. My friend told me about this place a loooooooong time ago but I never really had a chance to be in the area during dinner time to try this spot out.

New fave spot for rolls in the city. The quality is there, the flavors, the price, you can pretty much say that this place is the trifecta for sushi. I'm surprising myself because I used to think that Elephant Sushi was my fave sushi joint, but Takoba has me saying, "Elephant who?!" 

My bf thoroughly enjoyed this place as well which definitely is a plus. I think our favorite roll is the John Collins roll, which comes in 6 pieces compared to the other rolls (8 pieces). I think I can probably eat 2.5 orders by myself. Gotta carb-load before getting ratchet downstairs, right?! 

Btw--also newly discovered from a friend whose man had connects with peeps downstairs at the bar. There's a spicy margarita (I think it's infused w/ habenero peppers--super delicious, if you're into spicy things like me. The spicy marg literally burns your throat. I think you can order that during your dinner (once the upstairs got too packed, patrons were able to sit at the bar downstairs to drink and grub), if not, it's worth the trek to order from the bartenders downstairs!
author: Denise L.

description:
Great place. Really small inside so get there early. They used to be only open for dinner but now serve lunch as well. Service can be a bit slow and the rolls are really tiny(which sucks) but it's worth it. Really good/fresh rolls. Around $13-$16. 
- John Collins
- Takoba 
Are my two faves.

I'd go back :)
author: Sandy M.

description:
I came here on a Friday afternoon during the lunch rush with the coworker of mine. Originally we could not find the restaurant because it wasn't very obvious. When you walk in, there is a coffee shop in front and a bar in the back. After looking confused for a bit, I was instructed that the restaurant was actually upstairs. 

The restaurant is actually pretty small; it could maybe seat 15-18 people. However, we were still seated fairly quickly. The servers were overall attentive. Both my coworker and I ordered the Chef's Choice Chirashi bowl (for $22 each). The fish was fresh and in decent size.

Overall, I would recommend as the food and service was pretty good, but would not recommend during the lunch rush due to the size of the location and can be relatively hot due to being on the second floor.
author: Wilbur C.

description:
Was grabbing a drink nearby when I had a sudden and dramatic sushi craving. I looked up reviews and saw this place. Was a little hard to find since I had no idea it's tucked away inside of a bar that's downstairs (which adds to its charm) but once we found it, we felt extra accomplished.

Takoba is a little sushi spot that kinda feels like a speakeasy. It's a loft-type setup so the sushi bar overlooks John Colins? below-- super cool. It's small and cozy with only a few tables and very limited seating, so we were surprised that a table was clearing just as we walked upstairs. 

We ordered a bottle of sake and let the waitress suggest a few rolls. Each one was DELICIOUS! I'm usually pretty picky with sushi and it was strange to blindly trust someone but I'm glad I did. The sashimi was good, but this will have to be my go-to spot for specialty rolls. They aren't cheap ($15 per) but they are so satisfying. 

Expensive dinner but worth it.  It was a Friday night so the music downstairs was very much clubby and the bathrooms are shared with the bar so they are pretty gross, hence the docked star. But I would certainly return during non-peak bar hours!
author: Priyanka C.

description:
I've been wanting to come here for weeks after I heard some coworkers raving about it. It's on a side street so it's kind-of hard to find to start with, but then it's also on the second floor of a bar which is the start of a few problems with Takoba. 

Another concern was that Asian people don't work at Takoba! That should've been a red flag. 

The bar is loud, impersonal, and overwhelming. You have to show ID to get in the door even if all you want is Takoba. It's confusing because Takoba will tell you you can wait in the tiny area upstairs, outside, or at the bar. So even though we put ourselves on the waitlist via Yelp app and they gave us a time to be there by, we still had to wait. So what did we do? We waited at the bar, as they suggested. 

One confusing aspect is that you can order sushi at the bar. So after a bad tech meetup where this recent dropout pitched me his crypto startup idea (and debated the ethics of ethereum and blockchain) we did what any hungry person would do: we ordered sushi at the bar to speed things up. Then we got a text message saying our table was ready. Score! The barman said we could go up, so we went up. 

Takoba wait staff seated us at our table (which was a communal table, fine, it's as intimate as the bar but quieter! Still a step up from where we were, literally and figuratively!)

Takoba staff gave us menus, and gave us waters. I was quenched! The bar didn't have water. I gulped it down. We told them to take our menus, we'd already ordered. Aaaand then they told us to leave and go back to the bar because they couldn't give us our food that we'd ordered FROM THEM down there even though we were told we could order down there and then told by someone else at the bar that we could eat it at our table UPSTAIRS where it was crowded but not noisy. Hey, we wanted to chat like friends.

Alas, Takoba waitresses and servers rudely and loudly made us leave (I was so embarrassed) and we went back to the bar where we ate our Takoba, Midori, and Minna rolls in silence because we didn't feel like yelling to be heard. 

They were good rolls but not worth the price and definitely not worth the service. Until Takoba learns how to treat customers (hey, the customer is always right, ESPECIALLY when multiple people say the same thing and we--the customers--do it.) 

Save your money (those were pricey rolls, even for SF), save your breath, and save the stress and embarrassment (also secondhand embarrassment, because other customers asked why we couldn't stay at our table either) and go to Pabu or Akiko's (both also in FiDi) or venture to Ebisu in Inner Sunset.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
Yum yum! A little hidden gem above a bar, Takoba may be hard to find if it's your first time. You have to walk into John Colins then go to your left to head up the stairs. The place is very very small. It's also a little stuffy up there even with the windows open. Nonetheless, the food was great!

Ordered 3 rolls to share among 2 people and it was the perfect amount. I like salmon so of course all the rolls we ordered had salmon in it! Salmon avocado was a good decent roll. My favorite would have to be the Midori! Salmon on top with some avocado and cucumbers inside. A very basic roll but it tasted so good! The Takoba was a nice little kick of spicy tuna on the inside. The wasabi aioli on top wasn't too noticeable but the spicy tuna was definitely noticeable. 

All in all, I will be back to try more rolls or just order the same ones!! Someone answered a question on here saying they don't do takeout until dinner but that is not true!! I asked and they do takeout for lunch so I'll most likely be doing that!
author: Kristie L.

description:
This place is... interesting. You have go to into the bar on the first floor and take a flight of stairs to get to the sushi bar on the second floor. There are only a few seats and feels a bit cramped. We got seated by the window and spent our meal staring at a poor homeless guy who was showing off his butt to us as we ate our meal...

The ambiance aside, the place is rather cute and I admire what they were able to do with the space. We both got chirashi bowls; I got the standard one and the hubby got the sake one (with just salmon and avocado). It didn't look like much food when we first got our food but it was filling enough.

Everyone around us were mostly getting rolls so maybe we will try some of that next time.
author: Michele L.

description:
Not worth it. Over hype on the reviews. 

-Tuna sashimi sucked
-Salmon sashimi was good
-John Collins was fine but nothing special. More just crab and mayo flavor 
-spicy hibachi roll was my fav but still whatever 


Overall, do not recommend. So small. Awkward bar stools that are too high for the counter. Very mediocre. Go somewhere else.

Its more of a 2.
author: Nakita H.

description: Tiny little sushi bar tucked above a bar - we had so much trouble finding it! But boy was the food amazing. Their rolls were unique and I enjoyed every single one we tried.
author: Rachel A.

description:
As I walked up to the restaurant I was stopped and asked for ID. LOL. Not realizing this was a bar you walk through it was still strange but oh to feel under 21 again!

So you walk upstairs to a TINY cramped eating area. There are 20 seats and you shouldn't mind rubbing elbows with your neighbor.

Service was ok, not great and food took a long time to come out at periodic intervals.  After 25 minutes waiting for one item (remember there are only 20 seats) and at least two guys behind the counter at all times, it got a bit frustrating.

Prices for the size of the roll are definitely on the steep side.

The not so highlight is sitting and looking at the homeless guy with his toes hanging out his shoe across the street which is typical for many an alley location in SF and this was no different.

The fish was fresh but the amount of fish on a roll is 50% less than elsewhere for hefty $15.00 tag.  The stools you sit on are square metal bar stools with no back and for me were not relaxing considering I was cramped in a corner.

If you are looking for sushi and you are right there then it's an ok spot but nothing I would travel for in S.F. With all the many options in the area, just 3 stars for me.

Again fresh fish but the whole experience was just ok.
author: Jay G.

description:
What an awesome, tucked away spot for sushi!

I really didn't know what I was getting into when my maps app directed me to John Collins for the address. Thankfully, an John Collins employee -- probably used to the confused looks -- asked if I was there for sushi and then directed me upstairs. 

And then upstairs is probably 20 seats -- tops. But that just means they can focus on making truly great sushi for a small group.

I got the Spicy Shrimp Tempura roll -- I believe it's the "Oban" roll -- and a California roll (sometimes you gotta just go basic). 

The tempura roll was by far my favorite. Even though it was a tempura roll, that didn't mean that this whole roll was overly fried. The fried shrimp was just a part of this roll. And the California roll was perhaps the best C roll that I've ever had. 

Bonus: You can get on the waitlist via the Yelp app, so even though this restaurant is teeny, you can get a table when you need it. You can also order takeout from the Yelp app. 

The service was fast and accommodating. I come to San Francisco about once a year and will be making it a point to come back to this spot.
author: Emily H.

description:
Prices: 
Minna Roll $15
Midori Roll $14
Chirashi bowl $25

It took me some time to find this place. There is no storefront that you can see from the street. Walk into John Collins (the bar) and go up the stairway on the left. There should be a banner directing you to the stairway. Takoba SF is a small balcony area above the bar. You can imagine then that seating is tight. There aren't too many seats, and there isn't much space for you to wait either. It might be a cute place to bring a date, but pick somewhere else if you're planning on celebrating with a large group of friends. 

This place gets 5 stars because it has good food and is generally a good value for San Francisco. The price to quality ratio hit the spot for me. Of the three things we ordered. my favorite was the Minna Roll. The Minna Roll had a lot going on in terms in flavors and textures that kept it interesting. It had spicy crab and cucumber topped with hamachi, unagi, and tobiko. We also got the Midori roll because I love salmon. The Midori was good, but paled in comparison to the Minna for me. The chirashi bowl was beautiful. The fish was of good quality, but a bit pricey. If I come back, I might just opt for a third roll instead. 

In short, food was of good quality and reasonably priced. Worth a visit if you're in the area.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
If you aren't drunk while reading this, I would suggest you skip this place.  The people who own and work at this restaurant have no concept of how to do so. 
Brief Recap:  I go in and people stare at me blankly as if they are confused as to why I'm there. I have to ask to confirm if I'm in the right place. I'm told to sit anywhere and a waitress will come by. 15 minutes later, I go ask if there actually is a waitress. I am reassured that one will appear soon. She finally does and I order everything at once. Instead of going to place my order, she goes to another table and takes an order for a table of six. Surely, she will enter my two little sushi rolls first right? Nope! 

I watch as the party is served an abundance of food and I am just sitting there patiently. Apparently, they had poor service as well because they had to repeatedly request plates, soy sauce, etc to eat the food they were served.  Finally, I ask them to check on my food and box it to go. Then she realizes she gave it away to someone else... After another 15 minutes, I finally get food, wait ten minutes to pay and thankfully escape.  They gave me $5 off for being patient enough to stay. I tipped 10% for the first time in my life and went back to eat at the hotel.  Finally for the food- it was really freaking good! Who knew!! 2 stars for good food- and for never ever going back.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Sadly, I can't say I was too impressed. Takoba is a cozy sushi restaurant right in the upstairs of John Collin's bar. Seating and service were quick and friendly and the view out through the windows of the Mourad kitchen is nice.

Overall, however, I felt the food was just... okay. They did not have any hot tea, though the miso soup was tasty. The rolls we had (including the Minna and John Collins) weren't very memorable in taste. The chirashi bowl also wasn't that flavorful and somewhat pricey. In terms of overall value, for two people without drinks, we spent over a hundred for dinner.
author: Mikey J.

description:
When in San Francisco, you have to get sushi, right? I was in SF for another work trip and wanted to some tasty sushi grub near my office in Soma. My coworkers recommended trying out Takoba and luckily I did, because Takoba did not disappoint! I'm not much of a sushi snob, but haven't had much luck finding stellar sushi while in SF.

For starters, it's a small restaurant located in the loft of a bar called John Collins. Because I was riding solo, I was seated immediately at the bar around 5:30pm. I started off with a Moscow mule, which was served in a glass mug but still delicious. I then ordered the California roll, the Spicy Tuna roll, and the Oban roll. Would recommend all 3, though the Oban was a specialty roll. Basic rolls were $8/$9, while the Oban was $15.

Service was prompt and friendly, though there was a healthy amount of people coming and going, likely for their happy hour from 5-7pm. If you're done with your meal and want to stick around, you're conveniently located in a bar so it's kind of convenient. 

One of the better sushi spots I've been to in the city, would highly recommend trying out Takoba, though beware of the steeper prices. I'll still be back.
author: Jordan B.

description:
What a great little hole in the wall sushi restaurant.  I say that because it is one of the smallest restaurants I've been to in the city.  Size doesn't matter, it's the quality that will keep you coming back!! The great experience starts as soon as you come up the stairs, oh, it's inside the John Colin's bar, upstairs.  I was greeted at the top of the stairs and seated looking out the window, very nice.  The service is great and prompt. I ordered the Takoba Roll, spicy tuna, and cucumber roll topped with maguro, Cento coffee sauce, green onions and fresh shallots, and it was fresh and flavorful.  I also ordered a Midori Roll, Salmon, shiso, cucumber, avocado, ponzu sauce and sesame seeds, as the first, fresh and flavorful.  I also had to have a Sapporo.
I would absolutely come back and recommend.
author: David E.

description:
Great sushi in Fidi, pretty much your standard delicious sushi! They don't have too many varieties of fish but what they do have is fresh. The rolls are really good but all rolls kinda taste the same amirite, especially when they have jalapeno.

$65 for two people incl tip/tax - we ordered two rolls and one chirashi bowl. Would come back!
author: Michelle R.

description:
3.25/5
Takoba is located in the upstairs of the John Collin's bar. Depending on the day this place can be completely packed or semi empty. You can also order sushi downstairs in the bar area and get it brought down or you can try your luck at sneaking a seat upstairs. On a Thursday night the bar was packed and the upstairs wait was over an hour. Ended up coming on a Saturday around 5:15pm and the place was empty though people slowly tricked in over the next half hour. You can also add your name on a virtual waitlist through Yelp though the list doesn't open right at 5pm.

Food for the most part was alright. A lot of the rolls sounded amazing but flavorwise were just average. My friend and I split 2 rolls (John Colin's and Oban) and I got a Minna Roll on the side.

None of the rolls were all that distinguishable. Not saying they didn't taste different versus all the flavors were fairly muddled and nothing really stood out about any of the rolls. Rice had ok texture but lacked flavor.

Oban: I adore walu and that was the main thing this roll had going for it. Otherwise it tasted fairly generic. Basically a shrimp tempura roll with various fish on top. I enjoyed it but it wasn't all that different from a more typical sushi joint (3.5/5)

John Colin's: I did enjoy the tequila cured salmon on the John Colin's but it's a subtle taste that completely gets washed out by everything else. I only tasted it when I ate the salmon separately. I think I would have preferred this without the teriyaki which overpowered some of the other flavors (3.5/5)

Minna Roll: Probably my least favorite of the rolls because the sauce they used on the eel was overpoweringly sweet. Eel was also a bit dry. Close to a good roll if the eel was less sweet (3/5)

Overall Takoba was a bit disappointing considering all the reviews. It was still very cute to eat here and it's a fun place if you want a light meal and drinks but if you're looking for good rolls, this isn't the spot.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Why 5 stars? Because it hits the convenient and delicious bullseye.

   ---   ---   ---

I work for Yelp and was in town for a conference. I was asked to organize a small lunch group, so I opened up Yelp and did a search for restaurants near the office. When I saw Takoba, I was so pleasantly surprised - 4.5 stars and it's literally 900 feet away from the Yelp's front door? Amazing! I didn't even need to continue my search because I'd found *the one.*

And fortunately, those reviews did not let me down. I enjoyed both the Special Xtra and the Tuna Poke very much. It had been a while since I'd last had sushi and Takoba was a great way to re-acclimate myself to the raw fish world. As soon as each bite hit my lips, I was overwhelmed with freshness and an abundance of flavor. I'm just going to go ahead and assume that all of their rolls are great because it was pain-staking to choose which ones to go with, and now they've officially won me over for life after experiencing those two delights. My dining mate ordered one of the bowls, and while I enjoyed it, the sushi rolls are what really left an impression.

Takoba is absolutely tiny. It's actually inside of another business - walk inside John Collins, head to the left, up the staircase, and you'll find yourself inside of a sushi restaurant with about 20 community-style seats. They utilize Nowait, but we fortunately did not have to use it because there are some open seats when I arrived. Within a few minutes (just after noon) there were no more openings, so I'd definitely recommend keeping an eye on that waitlist!
author: Brett N.

description: Worth the wait! Flavorful miso and well balanced and creative rolls, The Minna and John Collins pictured below. Service was quick and attentive. The space only fits about 20 and often busy, grab a drink at the bar downstairs and use Yelp's live wait feature to put your name on the wait list!
author: Rad A.

description:
I went here for lunch during work one day. I actually never even heard of this place! It's cute and kind of like a hidden spot in the city. It's upstairs at the John Collins building (also the coffee place downstairs has some pretty bomb coffee too!)

We were lucky we came earlier in the lunch rush around noon and there were just two of us so we were able to find seats right away. But 15 minutes later and there was a wait. Its a small place so theres probably only 20 seats max, but if you are able to snag a barstool at the window its a nice view facing the street.

Onto the food, I got the salmon and it was really good. The salmon sashimi tasted fresh. The rice had nice seasoning on it. It was a good portion size for a lunch. It came with some ginger and seaweed. I think it was around $19 which isn't bad for salmon sashimi in the city but I wouldn't typically pay that much every day for lunch. But I would come back again when I'm in the mood for a lunch getaway and treat myself.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Definitely one of the best sushi places i have tried in SF. You can also see them making sushis in front of you , if you get the right seats :)
author: Sharad B.

description:
This is your pretty standard delicious, yet kinda pricey SF sushi place. A wide array of fresh sashimi and legit rolls with a focus on the fish, instead of loading it up with a bunch of rice and cream cheese.

I'm obsessed with sake sashimi and they kill it! It just melts in my mouth and I want to order a million slices more. The yellowtail is also really good. 

I recently got the chef chirashi bowl for lunch and it was delicious! 8 slices of different sashimi so you get to try a bunch of different things. I'm not a sushi expert so there were so many different kinds of sashimi that I liked but I had no idea what I was eating hehe #embarrassing.

The place is really small and seems pretty empty during lunch (I was there at exactly noon), but I once came for dinner and it's usually pretty packed. It's a great place to come with a small party, but not if you need to get a giant table for your group.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
After a long day of museum wandering, we found a nearby sushi place. We walked by "John Colins" trying to find Takoba. I looked up at the large window on the second floor and thought, "Wow, that place looks nice. If I was really into bars, then that place looks like a nice location to hang out."

We passed John Colins and could not find a sign for Takoba. Turns out Takoba is on the second floor of the John Colins Bar. You enter the bar and turn to the left towards the narrow stairs. 

The sashimi was not great. We ordered both the Chef's Selection Sashimi $22 and the Season Sashimi $16. I especially did not like the tuna selection in the sashimi. The fish colors and flavors were not great. The rolls were a bit better and redeemed the food part of our experience. I enjoyed my whiskey cocktail. We sat at the bar against the window which provided a fun view of the large kitchen of another restaurant across the street. A homeless guy, who appeared to be in a bad condition :( , sat on the sidewalk in the street-alley most of the time.

Alright place. Hope they up their game because the tiny upstairs area is cute.
author: Thien H.

description:
The sushi was delicious and the service was great.  Everything tasted fresh and the rolls were very unique.  What the reviews won't tell you is that this restaurant is above a bar that is predominantly hipster.  The music was so loud on a Thursday night that we could barely have a conversation.  Maybe turn the music off....permanently so I don't feel my brain rattling off of my skull?  
Overall, the food was good and the service was prompt.  I give it a 4/5 because the setting was so overwhelming.
author: Shaun W.

description: Definitely worth the wait! This place surprised me because all of the rolls were delicious! They are the best that I've ever had. Great price for the quality! They nailed the sushi rice --it tastes great and there is a thinner layer of it. Also, there isn't too much extra sauce on top of it to mask the taste of the fish. For two people, we got three rolls: Oban, John Collins, and Minna. I highly recommend all of them. Perfection!
author: Andrea T.

description: The takeaway sushi was well packaged and delicious and fresh. Price is a little bit high ($45 for three specialty rolls, take out) but it tasted good so I guess I can't complain. There's very little seating there (maybe two longish tables that seat 6-8?) so I'm glad we ordered takeout.
author: Marilynn L.

description:
Smallest sushi bar I have ever seen on 4 continents. Holds a Max of 20 patrons. Downstairs is the John Collins bar with an enormous screen showing guys who have taken a break from their anthem protesting to play some violent ground acquisition game which is clearly a neo-fascist metaphor for nuclear war.
Got a seat at the end of the bar and ordered a Minna Roll, John Collins and some Salmon and avocado.
The place is loud.  Not a place for a date unless you already know each other well enough to not talk or yell like an italian at Thanksgiving. 
The John Collins roll is fantastic. Tequila cured salmon - whoda thunk it!?!
Salmon avocado is good but doesn't have the punch of the John Collins - nor should it. The Midori roll disappoints. No ponzo sauce and is rather boring to eat - back to Tequila cured salmon it is!
author: Joe S.

description:
Great sushi and service in a great location! The staff was very warm and welcoming, and stayed attentive to us throughout our whole evening.

The restaurant is located upstairs (on top of a bar), so don't get confused from outside. It is a small dining area, but worth a 20-30 min wait, as you can hangout downstairs with a good drink. The salmon sashimi was buttery soft and well worth the purchase. 

If you're in the neighborhood, stop by and indulge in some fresh sushi, guaranteed to make your taste buds dance in joy!
author: Daniel B.

description:
Yelp delivers again. I was looking for a sushi place in the area but nothing looked very promising...until I came across Takoba. I was so happy to have found this place.

This place is a tiny restaurant area right above a bar. Protip: Enter the bar and make a left to go up the stairs. Luckily we came right before the rush and didn't have to wait. We were seated promptly and orders taken right away. The service is phenomenal as they checked up on us occasionally but was never overbearing. With such a tiny place, I was afraid they'd rush us in and out. 

If you don't know what to get, get the Chirashi bowl. Fish was fresh and so very melts-in-your-mouth! The sushi rice was also cooked perfectly. This bowl is pretty much perfection.

I've tried several other sushi place in the area before and none has compared. Will definitely have to be back next time I'm in town.
author: Annie L.

description:
A hidden little gem in the streets of SF. Took us a bit to find it as we didn't know it was inside John Collins. The restaurant is a small cozy little place on the second level.

Food and drinks were delicious! Got the Takoba Chirashi, John Collins roll and a spicy hamachi roll. Fish was fresh and seared for texture and well balanced with sauces and vegetables.
author: Gigi K.

description:
Cute little spot above John Collins.  The have delicious sushi, a friendly and competent staff and happy hour from the bar below.  It's small but worth it!  Plus you can join the wait list via Yelp when you're on your way. They have delicious roles and nigiri.  

The thing I like the most is that the staff is knowledgeable.  I like fish with a little texture.  After talking with one of the waitress (sorry I don't remember your name!), She was able to recommend certain fish! It was awesome. Highly recommended
author: H R.

description:
Really enjoyed my lunch here today.  Food is on the pricier side (maybe I'm a cheapo but wow $8 for a hand roll) so I'd save this place for a business lunch or a more special occasion.  

I tried the Midori, tuna poke, chef's selection sashimi, unagi hand roll, and tekka.  Absolutely all of them were delicious.  The Midori and tuna poke were probably my favorites.  Loved the texture of the fish- basically like butter melting in my mouth.  I also tried the Macau ice tea.  It was alright, but I'd definitely pass on that next time.

Takoba is located inside of John Colins.  The sushi is made upstairs where there's a small seating area, but you can also sit downstairs and get the same food.  Service was on the slower side (seems that the waitress was a bit overwhelmed by the crowd), but she was really sweet and we got all of our food in the end.  

Would definitely want to come back here in the future.
author: Shannon L.

description:
The chirashi had really fresh fish. There was a perfect amount of food proportion wise. The flavors were great and not fishy. There was nori and fried onions which gave it the perfect crunchy texture paired with the rice which had a hint of sweetness to it - it wasnt plain rice. The fish melted in my mouth. 

The spicy hamachi was a great roll! It wasnt super spicy - if you dont like spice, just take the jalapeño slices off the top off the roll. The hamachi itself was very fresh. I enjoyed the crunch of the rice balls included in this dish and there were avocadoes and cucumbers in the filling.

This place is a great spot to grab a drink and some sushi in a casual setting. There isnt formal seating but great for happy hour with coworkers or friends.
author: Claire W.

description: Cool sushi place hidden on minna and upstairs of John Collins bar. We didn't have a reservation but were seated within 30 min or so. Having access to a bar downstairs definitely made the time pass by much faster. The sushi restaurant itself is pretty small and probably only seats 20 people or so. We were lucky and snagged 2 seats overlooking minna st. The window was open and it was one of those rare warm ish SF evenings. The sushi is very fresh and very affordable. Wonderful meal. Definitely a great go to sushi spot in the neighborhood.
author: Yin H.

description:
Came here with some coworkers for lunch. The sushi was good but the overall experience was underwhelming. 

We were seated quickly but the food took a while to come out. Some dishes came out in about 20 minutes but other dishes took up to 40. They warned us that things would come out progressively but we didn't think it would be as spread out as it was. Also, because we weren't sharing, this left some people without food while others had already finished everything.  

The portions were also small. Most of the rolls only had 6 pieces and pretty much everyone left hungry, even though we each got more than one item. 

In short, we all thought the sushi was good but that it wasn't worth the price (given the potion sizes), and wait time.
author: Jessie K.

description:
Good sushi and prices hidden in a cool little spot above john collins bar. I ordered the minna and the john collins signature rolls. Both were tasty tho a bit on the smaller side. I was still hungry after eating both rolls.

The john collins had spicy tuna, crab, and cucumber and was topped with tequila cured salmon. The minna had spicy crab and cucumber topped with lightly seared hamachi and unagi and chilli ubiko. The stars of the dishes were the roll toppings. The tequila cured salmon and spicy fish roe topped seared eel added some complex flavors I really enjoyed. All in all a good spot and im sure its clutch if youv been drinking downstairs and get hungry.
author: Sean G.

description:
Takoba is a cozy sushi spot located in the loft space of John Colins. The rolls are quite reasonably priced by San Francisco standards and also surprisingly delicious. It's really hard to find decent sushi in this city without spending a small fortune.
My girlfriend and I ate here early in the evening at around 5:30 pm. If you want to eat dinner here be sure to go early because this place will get packed by 7. We sat by the window overlooking the grimy alley with a not so pleasant view of the butt of another skyscraper and a couple of hobos smoking cigarettes. The place is quite small and cramped, and there are no scenic views to be had here.
Although you won't get a scenic view at this establishment, you will certainly get your money's worth in the delicious rolls. I had the Takoba, Minna and Oban rolls, all of which I would highly recommend.
author: Neivin M.

description:
Takoba is a fascinating little sushi joint that is a little hard to find if you're not looking in the right place (go into John Collins and go upstairs). It may not be the fanciest of digs compared to some other sushi joints but the atmosphere, the service and the flavor profiles make for a really fun sushi experience all-around.  

+Our server, Debby, was super friendly, knowledgeable and awesome. Great service. 
+Love the view and the location. As I mentioned above, you're going to have to go into John Collins first and venture upwards from there. The best seats seem to be the windows overlooking the street or the small bar area. 
+The best things I had here were the Minna Roll (loved the flavor profile and the little bit of crunch) and the Walu (melts right in your mouth, yum). The rolls interestingly seem to be more of the highlight here although there is still a fair selection of hand rolls that I didn't get to try. 
+Drinks are from the John Collins bar downstairs which also includes happy hour from about 5-7PM on most days. Got a bourbon press for $7. 

+/- We were fortunate on our visit that the wait was short (being the holidays) but was told/heard that waits could be up to an hour or more depending on your party size because of the small spacing. Be aware.
+/- Oddly the roll I wasn't too fond of was the Special Xtra Roll - we got it mostly to try out the Blue Bottle Sauce which was super subtle. Not bad but probably wouldn't get it again. 

-A little sad that they didn't have more sashimi options (at least the night I went) like uni and the toro - seems to be dictated by the amount of customers for their seasonal sushi choices. :(
author: John W.

description:
Note: Leaning towards 3.5 purely for quality.

Came in on a weds night and found that the seating was very limited. As such, we sat in the bar seating (John Colins) and ordered food there. In total, we ordered the Midori roll, the chef chirashi, nigiri unagi + yellowtail. 

Quality-wise, it was pretty good. The fish was fresh and doesn't taste terrible (not frozen or thawed for too long). The biggest angst behind the dish was the thickness of the fish and quantity of the food. Even for SF standards, I think the portions were much smaller than they really should be. There wasn't even a decent potion of of vinegared rice in the chirashi. For $20, the chirashi wasn't really worth it. I would much rather order $20 worth of nigiri had I known. The midori roll was pretty small too. My friend doesn't each much, but even she thought it was smaller than a roll should be. 

The nigiri were fine. I liked the unagi nigiri, the char-grilled was done pretty well and the sauce wasn't the regular eel sauce isn't purely a sweet teriyaki sauce. The yellow tail's nigiri piece was actually thicker than the chiarashi's piece. Which I think that's unfortunate. 

Overall, I wouldn't necessarily come back for their chirashi. Perhaps a drink and nigiri instead. This place is definitely quality over quantity, but if I'm paying that much, I would expect the quantity to be decent as well.
author: Alex W.

description:
A decent spot, pretty hidden from the street but it's cute and tucked above a John Colins near the Yelp HQ (lol). They have a happy hour menu, but there were only a few beers, mimosas, and margaritas. I wanted to try something interesting from the bar so my friend and I didn't order from the happy hour menu. My friend got the mezcla (I think that was it) and I ordered something with tea in it (I don't remember the name oops) and both were strong and had an interesting balance of flavors. 

My friend and I also ordered some sushi, which was really good. My only reservations were that one of the rolls (I think it was only the John Colins) only has 6 pieces, so the $14 price felt a bit steep, and service was kind of slow since they had just opened for the evening when we got there around 5 pm. Otherwise, the other roll that we ordered was really good (ah I forgot the name of this roll).
author: Jess L.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Tuesday around 1pm. The place was completely empty besides the coffee place that is also in the building. This was a little hard to find because their sign is small and not visible from across the street. Came here because I was craving sushi and this place had great reviews!

Ambiance: A little strange considering there is a coffee shop when you enter and it looks like a bar is in the back? 

Service: I ordered to go so the hostess took my order. I waited about 30 minutes for my food ( 1 roll and nigiri) when there was no one in there... that's just too long- so if you plan on getting to go- call ahead!

Food: I got salmon nigiri and the shrimp tempura roll. Honestly I wasn't that impressed by anything. The salmon didn't taste fresh and the shrimp tempura roll had to much stuff in it. A shrimp tempura roll is supposed to be yummy and somewhat basic but they tried to jazz it up and just made it worse than usual. Also, this place is pricey!! More like $$$. I spent over $20 on this mediocre sushi. 

If anyone knows of any good/ decent priced sushi downtown please message me hahah. Have yet to find it. This place wasn't horrible- just in my opinion not worth it and I won't be back.
author: Hayley D.

description:
It is a tiny tiny, cramped little place with no AC--making it a terrible place to be on one of those days SF is hit by an unexpected/ unusual heat wave. 

The rolls were decent, but honestly given the ratings I was expecting better. The fish was alright, the flavor combinations were just decent, but there was simply nothing special or unexpected about anything I had (we had "special" rolls only and chose two with the most toppings) but honestly tasted probably only half of the said flavor profiles.

If you're craving some rolls, takoba is probably alright to hit in the city (given our overall lack of good sushi), but keep in mind the space is tiny, noisy (right above the bar) and potentially incredibly stuffy. I wouldn't come for "good fish" though, only if you really want some rolls.
author: Su Lin Y.

description:
Came here a few weeks ago when my co-workers from NYC came to visit and was craving some sushi. They ordered some miso and the special rolls, while I opted for 2 of the small maki roll. This place is in the john collin's bar right off new montgmery and minna, so at night this places get BUSY. 

But for lunch there is more to-go, as there is a limited seating during the day. I did like my to maki rolls (salmon and spicy tuna), and the special rolls that my co-workers got were tasty (their words), but as I had a shrimp allergy, I could not taste it.

My maki rolls were $9 each (and special rolls were $14), so this place is pricey for a sushi craving, and worth it but only the maki rolls). The special rolls looked a little small for me.
author: Mei L.

description: Their food is so good. Sashimi super fresh. We ordered hamachi and walu sashimi, they were so good that we had to double the order!
author: Cecilia H.

description:
This place is actually pretty hard to find. It's upstairs in the bar and I'm glad my friend took me. 

My friend ordered everything (or more like he chose what we ended up getting) and it was delicious. Not a bad thing was ordered, so it was great!

Definitely order as much sushi as you can! I love the location and great food. 

Protip: get there, hope its not packed, and get some sushi!
author: Nina Y.

description:
Have been wanting to try this place and finally did last week.

This place is on top of the John Colins bar which means it's really convenient for food but also super loud! Glad I got takeout bc the place is pretty small upstairs too.

Rolls were fine. Forgot what we ordered but they were probably the most popular three.

May come back for convenience, but nothing that special about the food.
author: Cal C.

description:
Cute little restaurant on top of a bar. We totally passed this place couple of times trying to find it. There is very limited place but they do offer you to be seated at the bar downstairs during lunch time if there is no more room. 

Cozy environment and fresh fish. What more do you want for a sushi lunch?
author: Vanessa N.

description:
Tucked away in an alley and disguised as a bar, Takoba SF exists as a tiny little gem serving fantastic sushi & drinks.

Come on a weekday or call for a reservation if you're coming on a weekend or on a date. The space is TEENSY so they can only seat a very limited amount of customers at a time.

If you're lucky, you'll get a seat by the window overlooking the alley. What a treat to enjoy the breeze & view while enjoying your food.

Happy hour has wine/beer for $7 and cocktails for $11. A popular cocktail is the pink geisha, a refreshing lychee sake drink that pairs well with rolls.

Our waitress was hilarious, recommending one of their stronger drinks as a "good time in a glass".

Check out Takoba, then walk over to the MOMA to get a fantastic SF experience.
author: Monica H.

description:
4-5 stars is high, but this place deserves it if you are looking for an informal, small, friendly place with great specialty rolls. 
The hostess was a doll and our waiter with the hive hair, tattoos and piercings was off the charts helpful, attentive and had a great sense of humor (had to with our party).
We left with full bellies and smiles on our faces from the experience.
author: Richard G.

description: This place is super tiny (they basically only have 3 tables: by the sushi chef, in the middle and by the window.) However, you can get everything but miso soup downstairs at the bar (even though the music is very loud up there). The food is very fresh and delicious. It was so good, I couldn't even snap a picture. We got tuna poke roll and a chef's selection sashimi. Their service is awesome as well!
author: Irina R.

description:
This little gem is tucked away upstairs from John Collins. I've always been curious to dine here but I assumed the wait would be a nightmare given the tiny area (seats around 16 people total). We came here on a Friday around 6:30pm and luckily there was no wait! I suggest coming here with 1 other dinner companion only -- the wait for a larger party is not worth it IMO. Also note that it's quite noisy and you will have to speak up during dinner given the bar downstairs. 

We ordered the following -- 
Chef's selection sashimi (8 pc.) -- $22
The Minna -- $15
Midori -- $14

The sashimi was fresh and the rolls were satisfying enough. I wouldn't go out of my way to dine here BUT this is one of the better Japanese restaurants in FiDi.
author: Mandi H.

description:
I sought this place out based on the strong yelp reviews. It did not disappoint! I got sushi to go. It was great! Ordered the chefs choice sashimi (added the chirashi) and also got the miso soup. The soup was good but not the best miso I've ever had. But the sashimi....amazing! Melted in my mouth.  Go get their sushi now!

This place is tucked away above a bar, so just know you have to search a little to find this place. It only seats about 15 people or so, very small. I ordered via yelp and it worked great.
author: Melissa H.

description:
This tiny sushi restaurant is located on the second floor of the bar John Colins, super close to the Mesuem of Modern Art and a 5-min walk from Montgomery BART station. 

The food here deserves a solid 4 stars.

Positives:
+ Fish is so fresh, tender, fatty and melt-in-your-month - actually, if you consider the fish quality to be the most important element of sushi  , this place would deserve 5 stars 
+ Taste of food is creative and well thought out
   Top recommendation:
   Midori roll (top: salmon; inside: shiso, cucumber, and avocado) is the most uniquely-tasting roll I've had in a while. It had a simple, refreshing and clean taste. With the right amount of shiso to give it a floral aroma, thinly-sliced cucumber for the perfect crunch, and salmon and avocado for the creamy texture. 
   John Colins roll (top: tequila-cured salmon, lemon, spicy aioli, and island teriyaki sauce; inside: spicy tuna, crab (imitation crab perhaps?? Taste was not really noticeable) and cucumber) 
+ Though the restaurant is very tiny and feels cramped when you get in and out, the table space was wide and there are enough space for you to order as many dishes as you want 
+ Food came out within 5-10 minutes of ordering, great if you are starving 

Negatives:
- Drinks came after food was out (likely because drinks are made downstairs in the bar and had to be carried upstairs carefully)
- Our waiter was friendly but did not know about the menu well so he had to "go check" multiple times to answer my questions about drinks and fish daily specials
- Sushi rolling technique needs to improve! The John Collin roll fell apart completely as I attempted to pick it up (just to be clear, I'm 100% confident in my chopstick skills). To me rolling a roll properly is the basics of a sushi restaurant, so it was disappointing to see such amateur mistake. 

Lastly, some tips:
1) After you enter from the main door, you will see a hostess podium with a sign saying "Takoba" and an arrow pointing left and up. Follow the sign, walk up the stairs (see pictures), and you will be greeted by someone at the top of the stairs
2) Put your name on the waitlist on Yelp before you go, and be there by the time Yelp says to grab your seats
author: Maggie L.

description:
Takoba SF is nestled inside John Colins, a trendy bar with a good variety of cocktails and beers. We came at 6pm on a Thursday night and were estimated to wait about 30 minutes. Since they take your number, we went downstairs and ordered a few drinks at the bar while we waited and were pleasantly surprised to have our table ready 15 minutes later. 

Menu is limited to nigiri, sashimi, hand rolls, and special rolls. Salmon sashimi was like butter and they use less rice in their rolls, which highlights the flavor of the fish more. Our favorite rolls were The Minna Roll, which had seared hamachi and unagi on top of crab and cucumber, and the John Colins, which featured spicy tuna and tequila cured salmon. 

Just a heads up...it's loud in here. Really loud. The sushi space is basically a loft that overlooks the bar and you will definitely be shouting across the table to hold a conversation with your dining companions. The dining area fits about 20 people and it's all bar stool seating. There's one communal table that seats 8 people and we managed to squish 3 parties in. Ideal for parties of 2-3 people...4 is pushing it.They do not take reservations and are not good for groups.

Despite the cramped space and loud atmosphere, Takoba is a great find! The service was friendly and attentive and we were always within arms reach of a server when we wanted to order more food. Their fish is very fresh and offered at a reasonable price, considering the area. There aren't many sushi places in SoMa and certainly not at this price point. We spent $25 a person before tax & tip and were very satisfied!
author: Deanna Y.

description:
I came here because well, as far as my vacation was going, I was trying to fit all the cuisines that lacked where I lived at. Plus, this place looked like it had a nice view of the street and also the food here looked delicious. We had to look around for a bit because there was a lot of construction going on. But, after a waiter yelled at us from inside we got led upstairs to this nice comfy loft.   

I ordered the chirashi bowl and sake hand roll. Both were tasty! I think I was more of a fan of the sake hand roll however. If you had to choose between the two it really would depend on how hungry you were. And also of course you have a huge list of options as far as rolls go. Thinking that this place is right next to Yelp, I knew it had to be good. 

Overall, my experience was great. I really enjoyed the old school light bulbs. It really brought in the decor. I also like that it was a loft, it was part of the bar downstairs, but wasn't. I think both restaurant and bar profit from this as it gives customers more choices on what to eat and drink. This place is neat and should deserve some attention!
author: Bruce K.

description:
LOCATION: Definitely passed by this place multiple times (like many others) because of its under-the-radar location in a bar, but I kinda liked that hidden gem vibe! 
AMBIENCE + SERVICE: The restaurant itself is pretty cozy considering it's housed in the bar's upstairs balcony, but there are nice windows overlooking the street. The service was reasonably quick and our server was very nice and helpful, especially when I found out you can order drinks from the coffee bar downstairs (!)
FOOD: As for the reason we came, I'd say I was overall pleased with my meal. I do think there was a bit too much rice compared to actual fish, seaweed, etc. but the bowl was so delicious that it's hard to complain too much. I'd call it a reasonable price for what I got, but I wasn't necessarily blown away

OVERALL: Cool "hidden" spot, good food, would likely return
author: Isabella O.

description:
Originally four stars as I've come here for dinner, but one star deducted because they recently opened up during lunch hours, and I felt very ripped off. Quality sushi, but skimpy skimpy portions. For lunch, they have two options - chirashi bowls (various types) and hand rolls. I get it, opening during hours where you expect less people has its menu limitations, but then you should expect a better bang for your buck if you want customer retention for lunch. For $20 per chirashi bowl, I got a small scoop of crab, two yellowtail pieces, and two unagi. And the seaweed salad. THAT'S IT. I was actually shocked because before we ordered at the counter we asked the lady if the bowls were big and she said yes. I definitely filled up my stomach with rice to make up for the lack of fish :/ 

Side note, lunch seating is downstairs where John Collins is, rather than upstairs. Everything is served in to-go containers. Can't expect me to go back to work with a full and happy belly here... dinner is much better.
author: Vickie Z.

description: I've had this place bookmarked for awhile and really wanted to like to, but the sushi was underwhelming. I do believe the quality of the fish is good, fresh and soft, but the rolls themselves lack character and are rather bland. Even the spicy hamachi roll had no spice! I do appreciate parts of the rolls that add texture such as popped rice or fried shallots, but overall, I wasn't impressed.
author: Lexi R.

description: A lil secret place.  Sushi is good here. We didn't wait long to get in this place on Friday night . The bar is downstairs , with sushi .
author: Ying D.

description: Great sushi, menu is not super extensive. Small area over a bar. Overall great, I would go again. It's a tiny little place but a gem.
author: Olivia G.

description:
Very nice Sushi Bar.

Went here a couple nights ago to satisfy some sushi cravings. We walked here from our hotel so I'm not sure about the parking situation. When we got there we were told it would be about a 45 min wait. We went to the bar next door and got a snack and drink. 

When our table was ready we sat right in front of the sushi bar. What's cool here is that Takoba and John Colin's are part of the same. So if you want a drink from downstairs, you can order one since it's the same drink menu. Friday night they had the DJ playing the usual hits. It was a little loud for a sushi place but I feel the background gave it personality.

We got the Minna, John Colins, Midori, Something Extra and something else. Needless to say, all tasted good and the fish tasted fresh. Oh yea!! We got Unagi Nigiri too!! It was hella good!! A decent size too. I also got a John Colins cocktail which was suprisingly fresher than I thought it was going to be. Tasted the whiskey but overall it was very smooth.

Definitely would come back!! If you are in the area and want sushi this is the perfect first stop for a nice night. There are plenty of bars in the area such as Rickhouse, the Pink Elephant and Novela to keep the party going. Good location. Good service. Good food. Good times!! :D
author: Anthony W.

description: Takoba has fresh sushi and strong drinks! My friend and I came here on a Friday night for a quick dinner before heading to a show. The waiter evaluated my choice of drink (a less sweet margarita variation with cucumber juice) as "healthy," so I felt pretty good about ordering all the nigiri & maki carbs right away. Not sure it was the correct pairing, but I loved both the sushi and the cocktail.
author: Anya P.

description:
I had originally tried to visit Takoba for dinner, but ended up going for lunch, which was a blessing in disguise. Takoba is located in a loft-like space above John Colins, which is a bar. To get to Takoba, you enter John Colins and walk up a flight of stairs to your left just before you get to the bar itself. The restaurant is cozy, and probably only seats 20 people at most, so expect to wait for space come dinner (I was quoted 30-45 minutes the first time I called). It was quiet when we arrived for lunch, though this may have been due to the rain. It is worth noting that reservations are accepted for lunch. 

The lady who works the front-of-house here is fantastic. She also took our orders and delivered our food, though perhaps they have more staff at night.

The food at Takoba is fusion sushi, with good quality fresh fish. The menu is short, but sufficient to fill your belly on. There is no "omakase" option aside from the chef's choice mixed sushi. We ordered a Minna chirashi, 2 John Colin rolls, 1 Cento Bento roll and 1 Takoba roll. The flavors were interesting for fusion sushi and I would order the rolls again (examples of flavors to expect include tequila cured salmon and a coffee sauce forming ingredients in the rolls we ordered). The Minna chirashi consisted of 3 slices of unagi, walu (escolar) and a sort of crab tartare with what tasted like fried shallots bits (very tasty). My only comment is that the shari (sushi rice) for the rolls and the chirashi was either very lightly seasoned, or was only seasoned by the gari (pickled ginger) dripping on it. Perhaps this was intentional, but it ended up tasting under seasoned.

We did not order dessert, but there is a coffee bar by the entrance called Special Xtra that serves the good stuff. It is also part of John Colins and is worth trying (they also make some of the drinks for Takoba), plus the guy running it was very passionate about his craft. 

All in all, I will be back!
author: Adrian A.

description:
Takoba is a hidden gem on top of John Colin's. It's a small and cozy restaurant that I would recommend for intimate get-togethers or dates. Every time I've been here for dinner the wait has been around 30 minutes. 

As for the food, the fish is very fresh! I usually get 3 rolls to share between two people. I try different rolls every time I visit but I always go back to The Minna. 

Favorites:
The Minna
John Colin's
Oban
Tuna Poke

Ok:
Midori - The roll was good but I just didn't like the shiso
author: Poy W.

description:
Absolutely love this place. It's in a very convenient location and the food prices are really good considering the area.

I had a mescal something drink. Really well balanced if you like that type of drink and the Chefs bowl of raw fish. 

I highly recommend this place and the raw fish bowl. $24 and super fresh/flavor fish.
author: Carrie Y.

description:
I'll miss this place! Takoba was my secret lunch spot anytime I wanted to get away from the office and have an incredible meal without dealing with the giant lines and crowds that descend on FiDi/SOMA lunch spots between the hours of noon and 2.

This tiny sushi restaurant tucked above a bar called John Collins is some of the best sushi in San Francisco, with a simple but diverse menu and incredible fresh fish. Bonus - if you come for dinner or order takeout, you can grab a drink downstairs at the bar while you wait. Now that I've left San Francisco, I can safely let the secret out.
author: Taylor B.

description:
This place is a hidden gem. Went here on our first night in San Francisco. The menu is not extensive but, everything they do have is prepared to perfection. I highly recommend getting the chef selection of either the Nigiri or Sashimi. Also, the hi-ball was perfectly made.

The presentation was beautiful and every roll we ordered was delectable. This was probably the freshest fish I've had (outside of the Caribbean). This place is a must of you're staying in downtown San Francisco.
author: Steve C.

description:
Love this sushi bar upstairs in John collins. The sushi is really great; really fresh and high quality fish. My favorite rolls are the oban and Midori. The John Collins is also a good one. There also some other options like salads and soup, but you'll come here for the sushi rolls. 
Drinks are mostly from the bar downstairs so there's plenty of choice. The dining area is a little small, but it's cozy. Nice to sit by the window. The service is also excellent- the servers are very friendly and remember regular customers, of which I am one!
author: Derek M.

description:
Finding this place was not that easy. I didn't realize it opened out of another establishment, so I accidentally passed right by it without even knowing. 

On the day I went, the 2nd floor was closed, but that was fine with me. The bottom floor was still nice and spacious. I decided to order the Special Xtra roll. It had a word special and xtra in it. How could I resist? I do admit that I felt a little iffy when I saw that there was a coffee sauce in it though. Was it going to taste sweet? Was it going to taste bitter? I could only imagine. When I got my roll and took a bite, I actually didn't really notice the coffee flavor. It tasted like a normal roll, although still delicious. The sauce that I could taste was the wasabi aioli, which gave the roll a good about of spice. 

This place isn't too expensive, so if I were craving sushi, I would consider going back to try their other rolls. Plus, they have an adorable dog that just runs around everywhere (but not where they serve the food). I don't know if the dog is always there though.
author: Lucinda H.

description: Light crisp meal. Great for a 1:1 lunch. The space is above John Collins and seats maybe 15 people or so. They have a variety of Chirashi options around the $20 range. It's a nice, modest meal with high quality fish. I didn't really notice any side dishes like edamame, which would really round out the meal. Just a little more and I think this would be a 5-star place for me.
author: Young Y.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by this little place. And when I say little, I mean liiiiiiitle. Seating is really limited but it's conveniently located above John Collins bar so the boyfriend and I were able to grab a drink while waiting for a table. The sushi was good and fish was fresh and buttery. We started with 2 rolls (Minna and John Collins roll) and then eventually ordered another one to end our meal (I can't remember the last roll though). By the minna was definitely my favorite. 
Also some of the drinks they top with an orchid flower and it's the little things that turn me on to this place. Prices are on the pricier end, but I think it's still worth it and I'm sure I'll be back in the future.
author: Cindy F.

description:
What an adorable spot! Feels like a hidden place that you learn through word of mouth only. Well lucky for us, Yelpers helped me find this and I'd highly recommend it for a date night or night out with gal pals. Not so good for large parties since the space is so small and you'd be waiting a long time. 

Situated above the John Colins bar, come early to avoid a wait. On a Saturday we nabbed a nice spot by the windows when we rolled in around 5:45 for an early dinner. By the time we finished, there were people waiting for tables, but not crazy. I think it probably is better on a weekend since there would be less FiDi people coming after work.

Rolls were solid and super yummy. My friend ordered a drink and didn't quite like the taste and the staff was super nice about changing it. 

I'd definitely come back again.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
How I managed to visit SF so many times (and stay so close) without visiting Takoba is beyond me. NO LONGER! 

I was craving sushi something bad and there's no shortage of spots to visit around the area, but Takoba stood out. It's located on the second floor of a bar called John Collins. You enter the bar (which was hoppin' during Friday happy hour) and almost immediately you'll find the staircase to sushi heaven on the left.

It's a tight spot, fitting no more than 20, so I was happy to be dining alone. I immediately grabbed a seat along the hightop bar facing the window. Drinks come from John Collins, so I decided to try the South Padre, Tito's vodka, elderflower liqueur, grapefruit, agave, lemon and ginger beer. It was tart and refreshing, with a special zing from the ginger beer. It paired quite nicely with my sushi. 

To eat, I ordered a miso soup, Takoba roll and hamachi nigiri. The soup came flying out of the kitchen. It was a nice size and chockfull of mushrooms and tofu. I slurped it all down. Next was the hamachi nigiri, two generous pieces of fresh hamachi. Excellent! The Takoba roll combined so many of my favorite foods: spicy tuna and cucumber roll topped with maguro, salmon and jalapeño cilantro aioli. There was also something crunchy sprinkled on top which added an interesting texture to the otherwise soft roll. Seriously though, this was some of the best sushi I've had in awhile and didn't break the bank too much.

I would say get here early or be prepared for a wait if coming after 7:00 pm. Thankfully, there's a large bar you can hang out at while you drink and if you don't mind eating down there, you can order sushi too. I loved the atmosphere of the upstairs though. My seat by the window looked into the busy kitchen of the upscale restaurant across the street. It was like dinner and a show all in one!
author: Cassie P.

description: The worst ever in terms of waiting time. We joined the waitlist and it asked us to show up in 30 mins. We got there in 30 mins and they tell us that from NOW, we have to wait for an hour. So the "waitlist" time on yelp signifies the time by which we need to get there so that they'd tell us how much more time to wait. No kidding, this is exactly what they told us. Decided to skip, thank u.
author: Sharendran M.

description: Decent customer service, decent sushi, but not really that much seating. Not much more to say than that but my friend and I enjoyed our experience
author: Elizabeth G.

description: First time eating here. Eh. It's ok. Not bad not good. Just ok. Over priced for what it is too. We pretty much had every sashimi dish they had on the menu plus a roll some miso soup and a few sodas. It was about $110. Again just not very tasty. It wasn't 4.5 star rating in my book. I've had much better sushi elsewhere. I don't think I'll be coming back...really wanted to like this place.
author: Mac C.

description:
Was craving some sushi and Takoba looked enticing with its high Yelp ratings.

I came with a group of 4 and since the tiny upstairs dining area was completely full and the wait time was 45+ minutes, we decided to eat downstairs in the John Collins bar area. When you eat downstairs in the bar area, they give you a condensed version of the menu.

Even though it's a smaller menu, everyone was able to find something to eat (+1 star for having veggie options!). I initially ordered the Midori roll. While the fish was certainly buttery, there wasn't much of it and the portion sizing was much smaller than expected, especially at that price point. I ordered a sake hand roll, and while that was tasty, it was also smaller and pricier than expected at that price.

Not sure that I'd make a trek across the City just to eat sushi here but it wasn't like I had a bad experience/bad sushi. 3.75
author: Sylvia Y.

description: We had a really delicious dinner at the Takoba. Ordered 5 different rolls - John Colins, Oban, Giants, Spicy Hamachi and Minna. Each one was tasty, with really fresh fish and unique flavors.
author: Debbie M.

description:
Love the slightly hidden upstairs spot from John Colins bar.  Up the stairs and you're welcome with a small sushi place with high tables and stools.  My favorite spot is the table near the window where you can see the people walking by a floor below you.
Sushi is on point.  All 3 rolls we tried were good - our favorite is the Minna.  It's decently sized, about right for the price.  Service is good too, didn't have to wait too long to get stuff or ordered another roll when we wanted to.

There's really only one bad thing: the stools are TOO HIGH for the table height, making it very uncomfortable to sit there.
Maybe that's the point? It's a small place, they want you to be outta there fast.
Also, come early so you don't have to wait a long time!  I'm not sure I would wait 30 or more minutes to eat here.  But if you can get right in, do it!
author: Dian K.

description:
Love Love Love. Hard to find, in an alley over John's Canoe. The Sushi Bar is small (really... small...) so prepare to hang out at John's. But, John's is a GREAT bar so relax and enjoy! 

The Sushi is off the hook! Had several rolls. All fresh, great blends of taste and texture. I didn't find anything I wouldn't have again. You won't either.

So, please stay away, so I don't have to wait as long for a table!
author: Brad H.

description: The rolls were better than average but not the best I've had. I wouldn't come back here, very overpriced, limited options, not authentic, and worst of all the restaurant is 100 degrees when you're eating because they try to fit 20 people in a space meant for 10.
author: Jessica S.

description: The sushi is very good. The only concern is that there are usually too many people. You have to have enough time to have lunch or dinner here.
author: Yinjia Z.

description:
Takoba is an adorable little sushi spot at the top floor of John Collins (bar) on Minna street. It probably only seats 10-15 people via counter seating, but that lends to a quaint charm :). If you're lucky you'll get one of the 6 seats by the window, facing the street. Definitely a cute spot for dates - head to John Collins first for a cocktail and then up to Takoba.

On to the food. I had the Ahi Tuna Sashimi ($14). It was plated really well and the fish was very fresh tasting! It was on the lighter side so I ordered some Miso Soup ($6) too and this was one of the best misos I've had - very flavorful miso broth. My friend tried the Spicy Hamachi Roll and said the fish was equally fresh, but he was a bit bummed that it wasn't actually spicy, at least according to this levels. Overall though - high quality fish for sushi if you're around the Financial District!
author: Sabina S.

description:
Oh my gosh such plain sushi! I got the special roll, the John Colllins roll, and the Takoba roll. They all pretty much tasted the same despite some having exotic ingredients like the Blue Bottle aioli sauce. I really couldn't tell the difference from roll to roll. The fish was very fresh and almost translucent, so that's a plus I suppose.

The restaurant itself looks fun as it's on top of a bar near St. Regis, but I got the rolls to go so I can't comment on the service.
author: Philip C.

description: This is probably my favorite sushi house since i got here at California. Growing up in the Philippines where seafoods, fruits and everything  are all fresh (because we live close to the  sea) I can tell which is which. And that is the most importat thing when you are eating sushi.
author: Luzanta Caridad P.

description:
Oh man, Takoba's rolls are so damn delicious. I can't believe I live so close by and haven't been until recently! 

Takoba is a very, VERY small sushi restaurant, located on top of John Collins bar. It's a hidden gem in SoMa and I guess since it's located inside a bar you have to technically be 21+ to enter. There is a bouncer checking IDs at the entrance.

Keep in mind that since it is upstairs, it gets fairly warm... it's crowded and heat rises.

My favorite roll is the John Collins. The rolls are kind of on the smaller side though, but it is satisfying. The place gets super crowded so come early! One time my friend and I attempted to eat here but the wait was 1+ hour...
author: Janet H.

description: They say they have good sushi but in my opinion it's so not. They have this sushi rolls with crunchy pieces that taste like burnt rice or nuts and I think that ruins the taste of the sushi. The place is really small very little seating. The place is so hard to find and it's located on the 2nd floor of the bar I'm not sure what the bar is called but I think it's John Collins. I surely don't recommend this place to any sushi lovers
author: Anabel Pine W.

description:
Get the Chirasi bowl and never look back!! Honestly, absolutely no complaints here. 3 coworkers and I came here for lunch 5 minutes before closing and they were so kind to accommodate us on the gloomy Thursday. 

We all had green tea which warmed our souls, and an assortment of rolls. I had one of he chirasi bowls and 2 hand rolls. The chirasi bowl definitely would have been enough! If I'm ever in the SF area, I would 100% go again. 

The vibe was very laid back and casual with barstool seating and the restaurant is tucked away in an alley. Prices are fair for quality of the fish. No complaints!
author: Maddy O.

description:
Cool space, OK sushi, slow service -- would come back, but wouldn't suggest or recommend it

Big downstairs space and small upstairs space. I think both floors have the same menu. Cool vibes for sure, but service was ultra slow. They also forgot some things that we ordered and was still charged for them. By the time the check came, we no longer wanted those items and they did take those things off the menu.

We ordered a few of the rolls and a chirashi bowl. Nothing tasted bad and nothing was memorable. I'd recommend Elephant Sushi or even the vegan (pseudo) sushi place shizen over this place for sure.
author: Jeanie N.

description:
This place is so hidden, I had trouble finding it.  Who knew that upstairs of a bar would be a tiny little restaurant that seats maybe 15-20 people?

I love this place for lunch.  The Takoba roll is delicious.  The fish they use is high quality and prices reasonable.  

So good, I ate here twice in a week!
author: Jenny L.

description:
I'm not usually a fan of sashimi. The texture of raw fish is always BLEH for me. I decided to try something out of my normal comfort zone since I usually don't.

I got the Special Xtra roll (my friends got other rolls but this is the one that I ate so I wanted to review this). I was so pleasantly surprised at how FRESH the fish was. It didn't have a grimey fish texture that I had been used to with other sashimi. The appeal to this was the "Blue Bottle Sauce" which could have been really awful or really delicious. It ended up being absolutely delicious and I couldn't stop eating it. 

It was pretty busy for a Tuesday night but it's a small little restaurant tucked upstairs of John Collins so you might ALMOST miss it. I found this place by searching "Sushi" on YELP and this was the top spot. Totally agree with the other reviews, loved it here.

Wish I could have taken a picture but the boyfriend decided to start eating before I could. 

RIP, it was pretty though.
author: Adrianna L.

description:
Disclaimer: 
This is a review for John Collins roll only

$15.16 pretax for 6 pieces of sushi,  couldn't really taste the tequila marinated salmon,  but I could tell that they used quality fish.   It was like eating a imitation crab roll but with salmon on top.   Although there was spicy tuna inside,  the flavor was not distinct, and the mashed up texture just melted into the imitation crab. The only distinctive taste was the deep fried garlic,  that was a nice touch,  however this roll did not amaze me,  however it certainly isn't bad

I got a roll to go,  but I suspect it wasn't made when I called it in since I still had to wait a bit (total 23 min from calling it in to actual receipt)  I may or may not come back,  but if I do I'd dine in because of the intimate atmosphere
author: Tina A.

description: We used the Yelp waitlist feature and hung out, mulling around in bars for over an hour for our designated waitlist spot. When I went up to claim our spot at the designated time, they told me it was going to be an additional hour. I get that it's a small spot and seating is at a premium but if they can't correlate their waitlist to Yelp's, disable the feature. Hungry and disappointed.
author: Daniel S.

description:
I was on a trip in San Francisco craving sushi and this place did not disappoint! It's small and hard to find - upstairs from another restaurant/bar. It was crowded but I sat at the bar and made new friends. The sushi is reasonably priced and delicious!! I got some sashimi and it was fabulous - go with the head selection - it's a nice mix of tuna, salmon, yellowtail and seasonal fish. The rolls are also great - I got a spicy tuna with salmon on top. 

The service was great - quick with drinks and ordering and very nice. I would definitely go back!
author: Sam Z.

description:
YES, YES, and YES. Right about John Collins and next to Pink Elephant this spot is a hidden gem. It's quite the perfect location because as you're enjoying your sushi you can order any drink you like and they'll bring it up from John Collins below. 

DISCLAIMER: Come here between 5PM-5:30PM to get a seat. Come any later and you're SOL. If you're also coming with a large group make sure everyone is there on time since they don't seat you until your whole party is there/don't make reservations. 

WHAT WE GOT: 
- Minna
- Giant
- Special Xtra
- Oban 
- Tuna poke - substituted with salmon
- Salmon Sashimi
- Margaritas ($7) - GET THEM during HH! 

All rolls were divine and melt in your mouth! The rolls were packed with ingredients and held up well. Our group of 5 devoured all of them with a quickness. My faves definitely had to be the salmon poke roll and the Giant roll. They average around $12-$14 a roll. 

This may be one of my new fave sushi spots in SF! Not only do the rolls here rock, but the decor inside the place is awesome too so be sure to look around while you enjoy your meal. It's fairly new so be sure to come before everyone else hears about it.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
Oh wow the cirashi here is so amazing, I was wonder if $20 would be noticeable be better then the 12-13 dollar bowls you can get anywhere

Well, it is, it's amazing, and definitely an experience, environment transforms the experience and is cozy and fun.
author: Robin H.

description:
On a recommendation, I checked this place out for dinner after work. It's parked above the Pink Elephant/Alibi/John Colins bar. While it was pretty busy at 6:30, I was still immediately seated (party of 1) and ordered. Get there early to try and get seats at the sushi bar or near the windows overlooking the alley. 

First, this is not cheap. Their specialty rolls run about $14 each, and I ordered 2 for myself which was the right amount of food. Pair that with a beer at happy hour, tax and tip, the meal came out to be about $40. 

However, the sushi was absolutely fantastic. Fresh, flavorful and inventive. I will absolutely be back to this gem to treat myself to great sushi, and will bring friends next time to enjoy the happy hour.
author: John W.

description:
I stopped by here the other day for dinner with a friend. I got there at 5:30 and the place was already almost full. The entire restaurant probably can only seat around 15 people, but the atmosphere is incredible. It's located on top of the bar so you'll have to enter through the John Colins' bar entrance and make your way up the stairs. 

The service was great and our servers checked on us every 5-10 minutes which was nice. I'm sure a part of it has to do with getting us out of there rather quickly to seat others but I don't mind it at all. 

All the sushi rolls are under $15, and we got the John Colins, Tuna Poke and Minna roll. They were all delicious and contained a large portion of fresh fish. They mostly came with 5 pieces each roll and did a decent job at filling us up by the end of the meal. 

Their happy hour deal is $1 off drinks so take advantage and definitely go there right when they open at 5pm to take advantage of the empty seats. It's definitely a hidden gem in the city!
author: My N.

description: THIS PLACE WAS SO GOOOD. Found it through yelp and was not disappointed. We got the minna and Oban. Both were delicious
author: Teresa K.

description: One of the many reasons I love Yelp....I never would've found this place otherwise. Hidden on the top floor of another restaurant/bar, this little place has great sushi that isn't terribly expensive. The sashimi and rolls are both huge and delicious. So glad I came here.
author: Mike G.

description: Excellent sushi. Cool dive type atmosphere for small groups. Super good rolls. My wife loved it.
author: George D.

description:
Awesome food, cool hidden spot - reminds me of a hole-in-the-wall you'd find in Tokyo. Everything is good but the poke roll is outstanding! 

Make sure you get on the waiting list because it's packed !
author: Andy B.

description:
I went here for fresh fish. I define fresh as fish that almost melts in your mouth. Not stringy fish with a fishy taste that require chewing. 

I've been to Japan 3x and Japanese (nigiri and sashimi) is my favorite cuisine. This place's fish quality is 1-2 stars. 

Ambiance: Seats were metal stools. How is that comfortable?

Service: Lovely waitresses and staff.
author: Benjamin S.

description:
I've heard this place be called the hidden gem of SF...it's sure hidden! It's located inside another bar so you go in and go up the small stairs on the left into the restaurant. Place is super tiny which explains the wait. All bar stools and very little space to sit or eat.
