Food was decent, I honestly don't even remember which rolls we ordered but I took pictures. The one with the tempura inside was the best but anything fried typically is good. I was surprised the menu didn't have more choices for the sashimi and nigiri. Decent place if you want to grab drinks before or after but don't expect top quality sushi. Fun place for a small group or date night (but not intimate date night).
author: Melissa L.

description:
This is a wonderful, odd little place, upstairs from some kind of bar/restaurant.

The sushi restaurant has a sushi counter, a long communal table, and a few other places to eat. No reservations. But the star is the food. Really fresh tasting, great ingredients. The best sushi I've had in SF.  One step above your average California roll joint, but not super expensive. 

For some reason, only open for lunch. That just seems to add to the place's quirkiness. Not romantic, not great for a large group. But the food is the star, and I'll be back soon.
author: Richard B.

description:
Very interesting place. As many have said, it's hidden within the John Collins bar. We actually had trouble finding it until we looked on Yelp.

The place is basically a small room on the 2nd floor. Therefore it's an almost guaranteed wait, as there's linited seating. On a Friday night we waited about 30 minutes, which wasn't too bad.

We had the spicy hamachi and tuna poke rolls, as well as the chirashi. All 3 were tasty, although small portions. However, it felt like sushi that had been elevated, and the flavors were very unique in all 3 dishes. It's pricey for what it is, but a chill, modern spin on sushi. Not bad for a late night dinner.
author: Onik R.

description: This place was a little tricky to find since it is actually above John Collins, but it's cute. Super intimate with the other diners so if you want you're own space this is not the place for you. The sushi is pretty good and the servers were super friendly. I really liked how accommodating they were in terms of seating. I had multiple rolls and they were filling especially for sushi. I would go back again because it was really fun
author: David P.

description:
Cool location with good rolls! 

We got a number of rolls: Spicy Hamachi, Oban, and John Collin's and that was the order we liked them (John Collin's being the best one of the 3). 

Rolls are about $11-16 and drinks are also in the same range. We got a tequila, mescal, squirt drink (I forget the name) which was ok. Had a weird aftertaste. 

The restaurant itself is super tiny as other reviewers have mentioned. There's about 5 seats in front of the sushi bar, a small table in the middle and a table next to the window, which also seats about 6. We got the window seat, which was cool. I loved the decor and the city vibes. 

We went around 5:00 when they opened on a Saturday and it wasn't busy, so we didn't have to worry about getting a s. Service was great too!
author: Jess D.

description: Slow service.  Took forever for hot tea and it was a bag and a foam cup?  No alcohol during lunch.
author: Patrick C.

description: Unique sushi bites and reasonably priced for the location. I would not have found this place had it not been for a yelp search. This place is cozy (aka small) but servers were attentive and it was nice they had windows so people like myself wouldn't feel boxed in a small space.
author: W A.

description: Really fun hidden place with some seriously amazing tasting sushi. Especially the tuna poke one that is sauced. It's also a place to try the strange escolar which apparently can cause side effects in some people.
author: Dilys S.

description: Super small restaurant on top of John Colins Bar.  Took us a while to realize the restaurant was IN the bar.  It was my first time at the restaurant but I had been to John Colins before and never knew there was a sushi bar right above it LOL.  There is very limited space, it gave me a NYC hipster restaurant vibe.  I came with a party of 3 on Cinco De Mayo (a Saturday around 8PM) and waited about 15 minutes, the wait was definitely worth it.  The fish was fresh and all the workers there very friendly.  They don't have that big of a selection, but, everything they have is worth trying! We ordered The Minna, Spicy Himachi Roll,Giants Roll, and John Colins Roll.
author: Aryana D.

description:
Surprisingly good bar sushi!

I know they're located within the JC upstairs but I wasn't expecting too much and was shocked by how good it tasted, how quick the service was (it was super packed) and the price fairly reasonable for the area their located in. 

Highly recommended them as good sushi joint in SoMa.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Very small space on the top floor above John Collins. Note: You have to walk into John Collins and take the stairs to get to Takoba.
This place gets crowded, given it's small space and downtown location. I came here for an early dinner right after work and was able to immediately grab seats. 
Takoba has a small menu, specializing in rolls, nigiri and sashimi. Not exactly authentic, but more modern type of sushi catered to the young crowd. We decided to order a bunch of rolls. The fish was fresh and cuts were reasonable. Service was prompt and food didn't take a long time.
author: Helen C.

description:
Man the taste of the special rolls were great but the portion sizes were way way WAAAAY too small... I ordered 5 special rolls to-go, got home and it looked like I only ordered 2 rolls.
If you're not a fatty then this place does just right-- if you're into average to larger size portions (or are used to un-buttoning your pants after every meal) then I'd say go elsewhere where your money can roll a bit further (for sushi), so you can roll away satisfied.
author: Eden W.

description: Oh so tasty! Fish is fresh and delicious. Very small place but worth the wait. Had three rolls, seaweed salad, and a cocktail. Great service. A must do when in SF.
author: Mucho Mas S.

description:
Oh hell yes Takoba you made a girl feel some type of way! Randomly yelped this place and walked around for 10 min trying to find it since it's hidden inside a club but it's a small upstairs restaurant so be prepared to get up close and personal. I would say a party of 2-4 people would be the capacity of people you should bring. 

The staff here is amazing and attentive! Food is fresh and creative. I'll be back Takoba!
author: Stephanie C.

description: We got the Chef Selection Sashimi, and the Takoba and The Minna Signature rolls. Didn't like the fact that 90% of the rolls had tuna or spicy tuna in them. rather than other fish. The atmosphere is nice for a date but it's overpriced for the food. Probably won't be coming back.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Updated Review:
Going upstairs to the main restaurant area was a game changer. It's a tiny area, but totally worth the wait. Definitely try to get seats by the window if you can, love the table setup. It feels like an authentic Japanese restaurant. And of course, the food and drinks are still fresh and delicious. Best sushi ROLLS in the bay, in my opinion. Highly recommend trying all of their special sushi rolls. Huge plus on creativity and flavor. It is now one of my top 3 sushi restaurants in SF. :)

Past Review:
Yum the food here is delicious!! Fresh fish and perfect presentation. Definitely get the sushi rolls. They were the perfect size as well.

Though, I was disappointed with the service on the first floor. We had the option of seating on the first floor (another bar area) or upstairs where the actual restaurant is. They gave this option because the restaurant is tiny, but rather cozy. My friend and I were starving, so we decided to skip the 30 minute wait. Turns out the waitresses on the first floor were not the fastest workers.. took forever on our orders and forgot our water. Very frustrating.. The general ambiance of both floors was nice, so we could overlook the issue for now. We probably should've just waited for a table upstairs.
author: Jenny H.

description:
Great sushi spot downtown. They strike a nice balance between quality and wait time. The price feels very fair for sushi at lunchtime. The chirashi bowls are a welcome authentic sushi option where most fast downtown options are highly westernized mayo covered rolls or sushi burritos. 

Nice chill vibe from the fact that they utilize the John Collins bar for seating. Try the special xtra from takoba then Grab a coffee from special xtra afterwards as it's in the same space.
author: Justin S.

description: The food was super fresh and we really enjoyed it.  My only complaint was that I checked in and was told there was a 20-30 min waitlist... in fact, they did not even ask who I was when I checked in...  but the food was awesome.
author: Suzanne L.

description: Don't know if this place is good or bad.  But the description needs to explain its a club for 21 or older!   Looks like a dinner place and took my daughter only to be turned away.  Boo!
author: Kaila S.

description:
The sushi here is good, but the restaurant is.... deceptively small? Ok, maybe not deceptively, but not really what I was expecting. It's basically the upstairs loft area of a bar, that's in an alley way. Not really the vibe I'm going for for a sushi bar. 

Parking is really difficult, and once I got there, I was really confused by the bar vibe, ie really dark. Asking around, I learned Takoba is upstairs. Given the very limited seating, the wait is really long. The fiance and I had a movie to catch, so we ended up ordering take out, but even that took about 30min to make given the back order. It's an open kitchen in the 'loft' area, and it serves food to both people who are seated at the 'restaurant', and people who ordered from a limited menu at the bar downstairs. The waiters have to run up and down the stairs. This whole set up basically slows everything down.
author: Cynthia X.

description:
Went here on a nice dinner date for our anniversary with my girlfriend. What a fantastic little sushi bar above John Collins.

Super fresh menu, great outdoor atmosphere.

Emphasis on Fresh! This place is my new go to downtown.
author: Ivan C.

description:
The rolls are the highlights here. Out of the three rolls that we tried, minna roll (spicy crab, eel) was the best, had a lot of flavor and a bit of crunchiness. The most original.

Poke roll was also pretty good, but not unique. I would skip the special x-tra roll (california with fried shallots and blue bottle coffee). It's a bit gimmicky and the flavor structure doesn't not stand out.

We also had the walu nigiri - liked it. solid.

The place is very small. Food is served quickly, you may be out of there in an hour. There is not much variety other than rolls, nigiri, and sashimi. quick dinner place. Can be hot on a warm day, so dress accordingly.

good value.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Great spot, loved the vibe. It was very small and intimate so not ideal for large groups. Luckily we were just 2 and got seated immediately. The service was excellent, sake was good, food was incredibly fast and delicious. It tasted fresh and presentation was good. Miso soup was so good. Also got the Giants roll and would definitely recommend. Overall I have no complaints and will def be going back here!
author: Andrea A.

description:
Came here with a coworker for an early dinner. Because I read that it was a really small place, and a line tends to form relatively quickly, I made sure we arrived right as they opened. It turned out that even though we arrived a few minutes early, there were already 6 other people in line waiting to go in.

Takoba and John Colins share an entrance. In order to find Takoba, you will need to climb a narrow flight of stairs. Be warned, on a slightly warmer SF day, you will find it pretty warm in Takoba, even with the window opened. The menu is relatively small, and features mostly rolls, so that is what we ordered. 

We got:
1. Giants
2. Midori
3. Takoba
4. Oban

They all tasted really good. All the different ingredients really came together well. The reason why I only rated Takoba 3 stars was because the service was very meh, and at one point, we waited 20 minutes for 1 roll. I think that is completely unacceptable given the amount of people in the restaurant. The 4 rolls also cost about $54 (give or take) and we both left wanting more food. I also didn't like how closely we sat with other people.

I might come back if I'm in the area and want sushi rolls that I know will taste good for dinner, but chances are, I would travel away from FiDi to get better sushi elsewhere.
author: Carolyn Z.

description: A gem. Small spot, upstairs through the John Collins bar. Simple menu with delicious miso soup and chirashi bowls - the fish was excellent quality.
author: Richard K.

description:
this really is a hidden gem, tucked away in an alley and upstairs of a pretty spacious and cool looking bar. The restaurant/sushi bar itself feels very intimate. Perfect place for a date or catch up with girlfriends for you boys out there - take a girl here for a date, grab a couple drinks before and after. She'll be impressed by your choice of restaurant! 

I've been to so many sushi bars in the city, sushi bars in Japan, including one in Tsukiji market. So I am pretty picky with sushi and know what mediocre sushi is. Gotta say - Takoba didn't let me down! The flavors were very unique and just perfect. 

Come early (before 6) to avoid waiting for too long. If you find yourself waiting, have a drink, or two, downstairs. 

The chef first fed us a complimentary nigiri right as we sat down. We the  ordered sashimi and two rolls (see my pictures!) and it was just enough for two people. I felt that we couldn't have gone wrong with any selection and it was so difficult to come to a decision on our order! Having that said, can't wait to come back :) and I will reassess then!
author: Dana Z.

description:
The smaller the restaurant, the better the food. You're probably better off visiting with 1 other person than a group. Takoba's not a huge restaurant, they're placed right above John Collin's. Think of It as the size of a small attic. 

However, as you can see by other reviews - this shit is good. I had this place about a year ago for my friend's birthday and It was a group of 6-8. We gutted the wait because It was close by and we could hit up JC right after. I forgot what I had honestly but remembered quality was top notch at a very reasonable price.

If you're looking for a date night this is an ideal option - low key ambiance where you can have a great conversation if you sit real close, so if you want to be impressive, ditch your third wheel and take your date to this gem.
author: Jennifer Z.

description:
Such. Good. Sushi.

Tucked away on the second floor, above the bar John Collins, this place is somewhere you either stumble upon (likely drunk) or have to be in the know about. Hopefully, you fall in the latter category, as you do not want to be too drunk to truly appreciate this experience.

When we arrived, we didn't have to wait as the restaurant was pretty empty. However, I've been told this is rarely the case, as the restaurant only has about 20 seats (most of them counter-- there's only 1 main table). If you do have to wait though, it's easy to simply grab a drink from the bar below!

Once you get seated, I would recommend ordering one item at a time until you're full. Otherwise, if you order everything at once, you'll demolish it and not get to truly appreciate the fish. In terms of what to order, I would suggest whatever you like! Honestly, I don't think you can go wrong.

I ordered one special roll (John Collins), unagi nigiri, and salmon sashimi. All were absolutely delicious. The fish is fresh and the cuts are beautiful. When you have something that good, you don't need to dress it up at all.

Takoba is a hidden gem. No need for a fancy location or decor. I'll keep coming back solely because of the quality of the fish.
author: Angela C.

description:
I have to say how absolutely blown away I was by the quality and freshness of the fish. I was expecting the typical quality one finds--already a little stiff, with the fishy odor barely concealed. But no, Takoba's fish were amazingly fresh, buttery, and soft. And for that, I give this place five stars. 

As other yelpers have pointed out, the inside is tiny! There are a few seats at the bar, one main table, and one counter by the window. About 15 people or so were crammed in there (I definitely recommend coming with only one other friend--otherwise it's too hard to find seating). The restaurant itself is above the John Collins bar, which means you have to enter the bar and take the stairs inside on the left. 

I ordered a hand roll, salmon nigiri, and midori roll, and all of them were delicious!
author: Allison T.

description: The Sushi rolls were delicious, and my mate who doesn't do raw had an excellent Cooked shrimp roll.  Service was also very good.  Nice and small, upstairs place, just around the corner from SF MOMA.
author: Merce M.

description: Might have left a better review if I could get into the restaurant, unfortunately, THERE ARE NO KIDS ALLOWED. Walked up to the restaurant for dinner at 7pm and were turned away because I was wearing our 5 month old daughter. The waitresses tried to cite city law in conjunction with the bar downstairs as to why we weren't allowed in, but they serve food upstairs, so not really sure why that was an issue, oh and it was 7pm, no one was downstairs, lights were out actually. Do everyone a favor and note this on your listings and perhaps even in your window.
author: Ara Q.

description: 4 stars just for the environment, because I'm a sucker for charm and anything off the beaten path. Takoba is somewhat hidden away and upstairs from a dive/tiki bar off a side street in SOMA. Some coworkers and I jumped in here after work and before a happy hour to grab a quick bite, and the food did not disappoint. They don't have a full selection of fresh fish such as uni or albacore but what they do have is really tasty and they put together fast. There are only about 3 tables or so and a bar overlooking the street, so it seems like a fun place to run into and refuel while you're figuring out your next plan. Obviously do not come here with a large group!
author: Lauren M.

description: Came here to grab a quick lunch. They have a few options, and the order came out quick. For lunch, the price is a little higher than typical lunch places (which is expected because it's sushi) and a little less food. Pretty good for lunch sushi though!
author: Sherry L.

description:
Very good sushi. I was more impressed by the rolls than nigiri. Fish wasn't the most fresh, but still very good. The rolls were really well composed, generous, and full of flavor. 

Atmosphere is relaxed and the service is very friendly. It's easy to miss, as you have to walk up a somewhat hidden flight of stairs once you think you're in their space. 

Good value and recommended.
author: Robert K.

description:
Came here for dinner with my boyfriend. This place is hidden inside of John Collins bar. Super small upstairs and OMG it was SO hot. I felt like I was eating in a sauna.

We ordered:
John Collins Roll: Pretty good, fish was fresh, recommend.
Chirashi Bowl: OK, very small and not much fish
Hamachi Hand Roll: Decent

This place is OK and the reason why I gave it three stars is because portions are small for the price. Don't get me wrong, food was pretty good, but for the price, I could of went somewhere else.
author: Natalie L.

description:
This is a very cozy (small) restaurant on top of a bar (John Collins).There may be a wait, but at least you can grab a delicious drink at John Collins and enjoy the music, chat, people-watch etc.

The wait is worth it for this sushi! It's DELICIOUS. We ordered about 3 rolls to share and ended up getting one more for a total of 4! 

The tuna is SUPER fresh and delicious and the service is wonderful.

It's a cozy cute spot for a date night or catch-up with a friend. It's not great for groups.
author: Carina M.

description:
Awesome lunch spot! 
A bit hard to find if you don't know, but it shares the same tenant as John Collins. Found it and the cashier was super nice and helpful. I didn't realize their lunch menu is limited to hand rolls and chirashi, but we decided to try it (and so glad we did)!
I got a salmon avo Sake Hand Roll w avo and Hamachi Hand Roll, and both were delicious! Super fresh tasting fish, not chewy at all. The flavor was tasty as well, not fishy or anything. It was fresh, satisfying, and really good. 
My friend got Tuna Chirashi and really liked it. She said the flavor was great, and it was a lot more filling than it looks. 
Cool little hole-in-the wall and definitely recommend to grab lunch here!!
author: Kaeleigh S.

description: The rolls were actually quite good. Spacing was limited; not sure if this was due to Warriors Finals game or if it's typical.  I Sioux's definitely go again...always looking for a reasonable sushi place when I visit the San Francisco.
author: JeVaughn W.

description: The sushi rolls were good although there was an unexpected crunch to them I think sesame seeds. The mushroom miso soup was delicious.
author: N A.

description: Hidden little gem, small space but love it!! The sashimi is fresh and the maki are creatively done. All the food pops in the mouth and leaves you wanting more. I don't think you could go wrong with any of your choices on the menu. Service has always been friendly and great. I like to go around 8:30 or 9pm so the wait isn't bad.
author: Caitlin A.

description: Very fresh and flavorful! Nice and small place. Drinks are great! I liked the "hidden" feeling of this place
author: Mark I.

description: Bottom line up front: I had two rolls--one was amazing, and one was medium good. I walked from the Moscone Center South, and I'm glad I did! CONS: This place was tiny, and located above the Tom Collins bar, and loud, warm, crowded, and smelled just a little bit fishy. The Tuna Poke Roll was just average. PROS: The Minna Roll. It was fresh, crunchy in the right way, flavorful in the right way. Loved it.
author: Helen K.

description:
Hidden gem. It's hiding on the second floor but the sushi is reasonably priced, delicious and the staff is friendly. Been here twice and will definitely come back. 

Place is small so probably fit under 25 people, so there might be a line. Service can be a little slow, but nonetheless worth it!
author: Kevin L.

description: Yeah I liked it. The tuna poke was a miss. It lacked flavor, the whole bite itself was nothing to remember. The star for me was the John Collins roll, wow packed a punch of flavor! The chirashi bowl was full of good fish and set at a good price also. I will definitely be back to try more! Be warned: very small spot, but you can order downstairs if the upstairs is jammed and quite frankly really hot.
author: Guisela L.

description: Space is really small and loud since it's in a section right above a bar, but the sushi is sooooo good! Glad I finally got to try this place.
author: Lynn M.

description:
Hands down my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.

Found out about this place when I was looking for good sushi restaurants in the SF downtown district. Takoba popped up at the top, so I asked a friend if he wanted to try out this place after work (Friday night at 5pm). We had quite an adventure finding this place - didn't know it was on the second floor of a bar.

At 5pm (opening hours), we didn't have to wait, and we were greeted by the very friendly staff and escorted to our seats. We decided to split a few rolls between us.

The Minna roll (unagi and hamachi) was by far my favorite - the unagi is cooked to perfection and combines very well with the fresh hamachi and savory crab salad in the middle.

The John Collins roll is also superb. The fresh salmon on the outside meshed really well the spicy kick from the tuna and the aioli sauce.

We had the Special Xtra roll which was very unique -- never had blue bottle sauce on a california roll, and topped with seared tuna! 

Try to go during non-peak hours, as there is very limited seating (about 20 seats?)

Overall, a phenomenal experience. Been back about 4-5 times, and looking forward to the next visit!

======================================================

Coming back a few more times recently, their chirashi bowl is definitely something you shouldn't miss!!
author: Alvin W.

description: One small restaurant within three!! 80's music with Japanese flair. Food is delicious and pleasing to your eyes!!
author: Kimiko W.

description: The sashimi was amazing, I mean amazing, the hand rolls were very good too. But it is very small and very loud due to John Collins being downstairs from this little alcove.
author: Victoria N.

description: I eat a lot of sushi - this is some of the best I've ever had and while not super cheap it's definitely not expensive for the quality. Great sake and cool intimate vibe. Unbelievable -- def go here!!
author: TIM B.

description:
I just discovered this hidden gem in SOMA, great place especially over the weekend when only a few places are open around this area. 
Their sushi and cocktails are amazing! The miso soup so rich in flavor! The staff is super friendly and very accommodating, one of my friends couldn't take the spice on one of the rolls and they prepared it without spice for him. Looking forward to coming back for more sushi!!
author: Azul O.

description: Amazing! A bit hard to find if you do not know where it is. The location on top of John Collins bar makes it feel like it's a secret gem that you happened to stumble across. Seating is intimate & shared but enjoyable all together. If you get to sit by the window it's nice to look out. Simple settings. It gets crowded easily even during the week but with good reason. The Fish is fresh, the rolls are to perfection and service is quick. Everything on the menu makes sense! I will return time and time again. Love, love, love, keep it up!
author: Sabrina V.

description:
Dinner review. 

Extra special - 2/5
John Collins - 3/5
The minna - 3/5

Beers+ (Tricerahops)

Overall, "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description:
the portions may be a bit small, and the price may be a bit high, but damn it, it's good.

the fish looks and tastes so beautiful and fresh. and the fish to rice ratio is actually quite high, which probably explains the premium price.

previously open only for dinner, takoba now serves lunch, as well. it's definitely the best sushi option within a three block radius of my office (which is as far as i'm willing to schlep), so it's become my new go-to sushi lunch destination.
author: Connie S.

description:
~1 hour wait for this place, but they do call you - so you don't have to stick around if you don't want to (super loud downstairs at john collins). 

It's kind of like a speakeasy, kind of like a shared space. 

- Miso soup served with mushrooms and scallions - very tasty and glad it wasn't your typical plain powdered miso
- Tuna poke was super delicious, marinated FRESH tuna served atop 6 pieces of crunch avocado cucumber and other crunchy deliciousness. 

Would definitely come back!
author: Kristie C.

description:
Hidden gem sushi above a bar. You wouldn't expect to find such fresh and delicious fish above John Collins...yet here it is. I've had their rolls, nigiri, and even their omakase. It's (surprisingly) reasonably priced and I think the best in the area by far. 

I wish you could grab special togo boxes at lunch just because the sushi selection kinda sucks in FIDI, but restaurant opens when the bar does which is around 5pm. Service is great, I've even had my phone die waiting for friends and the bartender downstairs graciously let me charge my phone (ty lol)! The wait can get long quickly so put your name down and enjoy some of their happy hour drinks downstairs :) You're able to order bar drinks upstairs when you're eating too!
author: Allie H.

description:
This place literally has the best cuts of fish I have ever had in San Francisco. The fish is like butter in my mouth every time I go. I can't speak highly enough of the quality of their Sashimi. 

Not so awesome parts of it:

The spot is tiny and there tends to always be a 20-45 minute wait when I go for dinner. It is located on top of John Collins which is a noisy local bar for the companies that work beside it. 

But at the end of the day all I care about is quality of food and this place delivers everytime.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Hidden gem in the financial district, but well worth it! 
It's sushi bar above the john Collins. On a Thursday evening, I came here with a friend. Oh gosh, it was so crowded. Nonetheless, I was here for sushi. We were seated at a table that was shared with other patrons. Tiny tiny space but just enough for you to eat some sushi. 
We ordered five rolls. The fish was fresh, the flavor was on point. All the rolls have some special twist and ingredient that made them special. I really enjoyed the john Colin's roll, highly recommend. 
If they have a bigger space, it would be a better experience!
author: Christine L.

description:
Let me start off that although it is a very small restaurant the atmosphere is really
Good, i sat by the window and it helped by making the room feel fresh. Unfortunately, that is the only highlight of my meal. The portions are very small so I left still feeling hungry, take in consideration that i ordered two rolls which are usually good for two people at any other restaurant. I also ordered two drinks one of them had coconut and banana, it wasn't what I expected but I gave it a shot. It was define you not worth it. As for the rolls, they were average. Not necessarily bad but they were kind of on the bland side. I wouldn't come back, because it received many good reviews I decided to try it. Frankly, I was disappointed. The food looked so good though
author: Shirley C.

description: Overpriced way too small of a play to even sit down and extremely disappointed and I hate rolls that aren't wrapped in rice I don't like the black paper seaweed paper so I picked the wrong roll I guess but still wasn't happy!
author: Grant W.

description:
I'm thankful I stumbled upon this place, as there aren't that many great Japanese restaurants in SoMa. 

Takoba is a small, intimate restaurant hidden above a louder restaurant that I would normally pass on. Do not come here if you are in a rush: they do not take reservations, and also often have wait times longer than 30 minutes on weeknights - the staff are friendly and happy to help assist, but stern about the waitlist.

Don't be fooled by the small drink list - the Japanese whiskeys and beers were all great as well. We ordered various nigiri and rolls, and the quality of the fish is great. The presentation and make of the dishes are nothing special (no gripes there), and the price for this level of sushi is on par with the rest of the city.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
Can we all just STOP for a second and talk about how great this place is? Like seriously, STOP WHAT YOU'RE DOING AND READ THIS REVIEW.

Now that I have your attention, there is something you need to know. This might be THE BEST sushi I have ever had. Never have I had such fresh, tasty rolls than I experienced coming to Takoba.

This place is super unique in that the "restaurant" is actually a 20 ft. X 20 ft. Loft space above the John Collins bar. Small and COZY, yes. But so so good.

They have a great selection of rolls and beers to try, as well as killer special creations concocted by the sushi chefs. 

My friend and I tried the John Collins roll, the Tuna Poke roll, and one of their special rolls that had shrimp tempura, salmon and what I think was tuna on top with tobiko to add a nice crunch. Delicious.

I recommend this place 150%. Great service, GREAT food. Go check it out.
author: Anna P.

description:
The Ultimate "Chirashi" Experience

Chirashi means "sashimi" (raw fish pieces) over a rice bowl. It's a very popular way to eat sushi in Japan and I'm pleasantly surprised a hidden gem here in SF downtown does it so well!

The fish is amazingly fresh and the portions are just the right size per order. I highly recommend the Chef's Chirashi as it has several types of fish (salmon, tuna, hamachi, butterfish) so you get a good range of flavors.

The location is a little bit hard to find (2nd floor on top of the John Collins bar) but the atmosphere is hard to beat. Sitting at the sushi counter looking at all the wonderful specimens of fish almost transports you to Japan!

Overall this place is hard to beat in terms of quality and price, do yourself a favor and hunt for this hidden gem!
author: Andy Z.

description: For this price it's really average, nothing special. It's hidden and on the second floor. We ordered rolls
author: Why-Tie Z.

description: Cozy atmosphere on top of a nice bar, great sushi, good service, nice place for dates and small groups.
author: Bahar B.

description:
I don't remember why I had bookmarked this place, but so glad I did!

Came in after having one of those draining long days where nothing went right, so I needed my version of comfort food...sushi. Tiny, packed place, but was able to grab a seat at the sushi counter immediately. 

No frills menu. Got the Midori roll, chirashi bowl, and sake. What I loved is that they were ok with making substitutions if you didn't care for one of the fish in the chirashi or chef's selection. I honestly wished I could have ordered more, but I was legit too full to attempt another bite. 

Simple, yummy, fresh food that was  reasonably priced, with exceptional customer service.  We need more places like this! Will definitely be back when I'm in the area.
author: Jackie K.

description:
Hard to find, but worth a visit. Located upstairs in an alley in a bar, Takoba serves up some delicious sushi rolls and nigiri. It's a small but nice space.

I tried and liked:
-Special xtra (my fave of the bunch)
-Takoba
-John Collins 
-Minna 
(Rolls range from $10-13) 

I also tried the special scallop nigiri. My friend and I liked the scallop so much, we ordered an extra order at the end.

Drinks were nice and strong, service was great, and I would definitely come back again.
author: Corinna T.

description: Small venue but definitely some of the best sushi I've had in SF! Rolls and dishes are delicious and cocktails are yummy.
author: Marisa R.

description: Very very good unagi and sake sushi. Normally I roll my eyes at the sushi rolls (esp California rolls) but this place makes them very good. A teeny bit noisy and crowded hence giving only 4 stars.
author: Balu V.

description: Huge fan of this place! It's nestled inside John Collins bar (you have to enter John Collins to get to it). I went here for lunch and got the Chef's Chirashi bowl ($20). While it was more on the expensive side, the fish was EXTREMELY fresh and delicious. I can't wait to go back here for dinner and try out more things.
author: Sam M.

description:
Both confused and pleasantly surprised by this restaurant!

Firstly, I struggled to find it because it's actually a small sushi bar / restaurant inside another restaurant (I think they must be a paired) and up some stairs. There's probably no more than 15 seats and it's super cramped but the feeling and atmosphere is great.

The sushi was pretty good as well. We ordered three special roll dishes between two and it was plenty. The spicy tuna ones were great but we weren't the biggest fans of the salmon. That said, I definitely would eat it again! I think the menu could be slightly improved by adding a greater variety of fishes / sushis / nagiris etc but that is my only criticism. (Actually some more prominent signs outside would be helpful too!)

Would recommend having a bite to eat here if you're in the neighbourhood!
author: Michael C.

description:
Takoba has amazing sushi.

It's tucked away at the top floor of John Collins, a hip bar just steps away from the Montgomery BART station. They have a classic dollar-off happy hour selection. Since Takoba doesn't seat you until your entire party arrives nor do they take reservations, you can have yourself a discounted (well, discounted for SF) Moscow Mule in an adorable Mason jar from their friendly (and efficient!) cocktail bartenders and sit on the corner of a hip wooden bench as a perky cloud of SF millennials form around you.

I had their John Collins, Spicy Hamachi, and Midori rolls. The rolls were delicious. The fish was fresh, like they were literally just caught in the ocean moments ago, and the sauces on the rolls were fantastic. Really great flavors, combined with the fish just melting into your mouth, makes a great dinner.

And, the best part is, the rolls are well-priced for what you get. A sushi dinner usually comes out to be around $50-60, but I was surprised to see my check clocking in under $45, which is a DEAL in SF.

The one downside is that there is really limited seating. I feel like smaller parties of 2-3 probably have better luck getting seating in here. However, this downside equates excellent service--our food came out quickly and our water glasses got a lot of attention. 

Takoba is fantastic. I hope they have room for me at the table to enjoy their delicious sushi again!
author: Marcy S.

description: Good sushi in a small place located on the second floor of the John Colins bar. The place is cozy but can be quite noisy due to the bar beneath. The window seats overseeing the Mina street are quiet nice.
author: Yoshikage K.

description: Loved the location and ambiance of this little (emphasis on little) hot spot however the food was less then spectacular for all the hype. Sushi is our go to on vacation so we have been to quite a few places and this one didn't quite do it for us. The sashimi didn't taste very fresh and the rolls we got pretty much all tasted the same. The limited menu was also disappointing. They must be appealing to a lot of people though as there was a constant stream of guests asking to get on the waiting list.
author: Shannon F.

description:
Your first mission if you choose to accept it is to find this place. :P

Takoba is truly a hidden gem of SF. Hidden in a small room on the second floor of a bar in a narrow side street, this restaurant is not easy to find. It's really small with something around 20 seats spread across two counter-like seatings and one table.

I recommend the sushi rolls here, but then again, that's like half the menu. I've tried five rolls split amongst a friend and I, and they were all unique in their own way. My highest recommendation goes to The Minna in the end. The unagi is cooked perfectly with a nice barbecue taste to it.
author: Joshua M.

description:
For the quality and price that you're paying, Takoba is as good as it gets in downtown SF for sashimi and sushi. 

They do carry a limited menu sashimi selection but all of their fish is cut thick and delicious in its own regard. The salmon is soft and melts in your mouth. The walu walu literally tastes like butter (and I love butter). I'm not normally a tuna fan, but I'd get it here. Hamachi is also good. I've never had fishy-tasting fish here, ever, and I've gotten takeout at least 15 times....

The rolls are also filling, but not because they're packing them with rice. I've tried the Minna and Takoba rolls-- both were nice, but maybe I'm just not a roll person.  

As mentioned, I only get takeout, but the atmosphere (it's up the stairs, on the second floor of the John Collin's lounge) is kind of loud, if that's your thing. My only complaint is that they sometimes add a lime in between the sashimi as decoration. It looks nice, but the acid cooks the fish :(.

Hidden gem indeed.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Fish standalone - it's the best value in SF. 

Is it a small space? Yes.
Is there a long wait? Most of the time.
Is it loud from the bar downstairs? Yes.
Should you have an important dinner there? Probably not. 

BUT, the sushi and sashimi is by far the most fresh and flavorful I have tasted at that value. 

We had the variety of 5 nigiri pieces (2 orders), the John Colins roll (highly recommended), and the yellowtail maki.  (That's a perfect amount for two people and you'll spend less than $65, add drinks and you're probably at about $100) 

Lots of quality cuts and great rice as well. The fish to rice ratios are on spot too. Most of the pieces do not need soy sauce. 

Like I said earlier, I wouldn't bring my in-laws there for a quiet dinner, but damn, I might anyways.
author: Patrick M.

description: The most delicious sushi I've ever had in awhile. The waitresses are fast and the food came out pretty fast.
author: Kristine R.

description: Hard to find but the sushi and rolls were amazing. Prices were a bit high. Service was really friendly and prompt.
author: George T.

description: This small upstairs sushi joint is easy to walk by so take notice of the "inside John Colin's" description. Takoba SF is upstairs with very limited seating. The signature rolls are interesting plus there are plenty of regular roll options as well. We selected the John Colin's roll, Midori roll, & Spicy Hamachi rolls. They were all flavorful and fresh tasting. The Spicy Hamachi roll was most memorable with spiciness from a fine garnish of shredded jalapeños topping the roll. The roasted rice sprinkle adds a surprising crunch, much more crunch than sesame seeds or furikake. I will definitely come back but be sure to use the Yelp app's "add to waitlist" feature since it can be hard to get a seat.
author: Jamez B.

description:
Takoba is truly a hidden gem in the SoMa/FiDi district. The sushi bar is hidden away inside the bar John Collins and has no signage visible from the street. You should be prepared to wait and get cozy. The sushi bar only has seating for around a dozen, very closely packed people. Given how popular its gotten, the wait can get up to 45 minutes during peak dinner hours. They don't take reservations, but you can call ahead and put your name down ~1 hour in advance if necessary.

Onto the food -- there is a reason why Takoba has so much buzz. The sushi here is no doubt high quality. I've had the chef's choice sashimi which comes with a generous amount of raw fish. What I like the most is some of their more creative rolls like the SpecialXtra which comes topped with coffee flavored sauce!

All in all, worth at least a one time visit for any sushi lovers in the city.
author: Amy T.

description: The sushi was amazing...and we are REALLY picky! We recommend making a reservation through yelp as it is a small restaurant but it is completely worth the wait!!!
author: Gina P.

description: Very neat, small hidden place in San Francisco that's gives great costumer service. I expected really good food based on previous reviews but it was nothing out of the ordinary. The sushi was fresh and tasty! Our favorites were the Mina Roll and the Tuna Poke roll.
author: Alejandra M.

description: A little bit pricey for sushi rolls $15 a roll on average. But the sushi was SO GOOD. Tasty, fresh and actually pretty big. I will totally come back! It is located above John Colins bar. It's perfect. Get drinks downstairs and then come up to eat!
author: Marie D.

description: This is a tiny spot above another bar. There is no sign so it's a bit hard to find but the sushi is amazing!!
author: Ema J.

description: I had two things here - a roll with various types of fish on top, and two salmon nigiri. The bits of fish on the roll were delicious- yellow tail, spicy tuna, escolar, even salmon - but I was really disappointed in the quality of salmon on the nigiri. It was definitely lower quality than the fish on the roll. Not only was it dry, it tasted fishy and slightly of soap. Definitely not worth the $8 I spent for two pieces of salmon, and definitely lower quality than I would expect out of a place rated so highly. Looking at this fish, you could tell it was lower quality than the rest, and the chefs definitely should have noticed and should not have served that fish if they wanted their restaurant to be well respected.
author: Laura B.

description:
This spot is the definition of hole in the wall, nestled inside John Collins is Takoba! A lot of sushi places that I've been to value sauce over substance, but every roll I ordered here had generous amounts of fish, great flavor, and a tasteful amount of sauce.

I ordered the Minna, the Midori, and the Red Crab. My favorite was definitely the Minna which had a little kick of spice and eel layered on top. What made this roll so special was the way the eel was prepared. Instead being drenched in teriyaki sauce, there was only a drizzle which added to the eel flavor. The Midori was also pretty good, but the Red Crab was a little misleading. It's basically a really good glorified California Roll. All in all delicious!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Go to spot for takeout sushi rolls. I've dined here once, but it's a tiny place, and the wait can get long. It's also on the second floor of John Collins, so you get ID'ed before you can even enter.
I can't speak to the quality of the fish since I've only ever ordered specialty rolls here where the sauces masks most of any fish taste. Not that I mind this -- I'm of a fan of high quality sushi but when it comes to rolls, I'm less picky about fish quality.
I've tried the John Collins, Takoba, Midori, and Special Xtra (may want to order with the blue bottle sauce on the side just in case). All were decent and very filling. Even though they may seem small, I was pretty full after one roll. Be wary of the drinks menu; the one cocktail I ordered was pretty bad, so stick to beer if you order drinks!
author: Rebecca L.

description:
First off - it's the SECOND FLOOR of a bar. Take a left when you enter and you'll find a narrow staircase that leads you here. A small venue, so call ahead to check if there's seats.

A colleague and I got the following after a long day of conferences and meetings:

Hibaki whiskey
Sushi/sake sashimi
Blue bottle coffee roll
Shrimp tempura roll

We sat near the window (which in itself is the entire wall). That's how my photos turned out very nice if you were wondering.

Anyways, great food, great price for what we got.

I think the blue bottle coffee roll is something you should definitely try. There are just so many flavors that come into play. And this is coming from someone who read blue bottle xxx and thought it would be some bullshit marketing roll.
author: Albert S.

description: Small upstairs made for a cozy environment where they prepare the sushi in front of you. Cool decor and tasty sushi.
author: Kara S.

description: The freshest sushi I have ever had, on top of an amazing ambiance. It tasted as if they grabbed the fish from the ocean as I ordered. Also, the servers were extremely polite and attentive. This is for sure my number 1 sushi spot in SF.
author: Natasha D.

description:
I can't believe this is so close to the hotel we always stay at in SF. You'd never know it was there, were it not for a little app called Yelp. I came here with one of my all-time favorite co-workers, which definitely added to my enjoyment... and he's an adventurous orderer/eater, which is the highest praise in my book.  

Located inside John Collins, little more than a balcony, it's small but perfect. You're packed in next to fellow diners, Tokyo style. You take whatever seat you can get and listen up for the specials, because that is definitely what you want to order. 

We ordered almost exclusively from the specials menu and loved every bite. My only regret was that we couldn't eat more - like I wish I had skipped all the free snacks at HQ. Everything was super fresh, beyond perfect and presented so beautifully. High points for great drinks, due to the fact this is a restaurant within a bar, good service and a fun, albeit cramped atmosphere. A very urbane experience for those of us coming in from the hinterlands.
author: Julie S.

description: Great atmosphere and awesome sushi with the great folks from LoadDocs.  This place is hard to beat for the highest quality!
author: Gary K.

description:
Best friend and I used to think there were no good sushi spots near work in the city - but they proved us wrong. This is my new favorite place ever!

They have a pretty small menu but it's not like the restaurant is big either - there are only 20 seats. But their main source of income seems to be the bar downstairs - John Colins. We went between 6:00-6:30pm and there was basically nobody else there. So we were taken care of pretty well by the full staff.

I like how they have interesting rolls, like the John Colins (tequila cured salmon and other stuff) and the Special Xtra (something, something, and Blue Bottle Coffee sauce), that aren't super pricey - $13. I imagined that rolls like that in the heart of expensive SF would rob you of one paycheck. But this was amazing. Sadly, like all sushi rolls, pure bliss for 5 minutes and then disappointment when it's all gone because no free refills on the deliciousness.

Also, with our bill, they gave us a "gift certificate" kinda thing for a free John Colins roll with purchase of another roll, which is AMAZING! I've already decided that I WILL be returning very soon to claim that John Colins roll and to try another roll - won't take too long to try all their rolls anyway.
author: Athena C.

description:
5 stars is still low for this place. I'm absolutely in love with the location. My friend selected this place for a Friday night dinner around 9 pm. We parked a block away and started to look for this location. He told me the location is hard to find, and so we walked into minna st. We then we're outside a bar named John Collin. The bouncer was nice and

If you go onto their website you can read a quick history on this place "In response to our popular Sushi nights offered on Thursday and Friday,HayaHon and Jumpin Dumplin have launched "Takoba" on the mezzanine level of John Colins. Chef Mark Hayashida's petite sushi nook offers fresh and inventive sushi dishes throughout the entire restaurant each evening, set to the backdrop of great tunes and good times. Seating 20 diners in the upstairs balcony, Mark Hayashida's "Takoba" offers a selection of fresh, made-to-order sushi, including House made sardines with avocado, beets, English peas, pickled red onion, shiso, and Meyer lemon crème fraiche; Kauai Ahi Poke with Koloa rum sea salt, furikake, hijiki seaweed, sesame teri dressing, and shaved green onions; Seasonal nigiri with daily seasonal sushi such as Umi Masu (ocean trout), Kona Kampachi (Hawaiian amberjack), Escolar, Surume Ika, Uni, Saba, Hamachi, Toro, and Iwashi (Japanese sardines). In addition, selections such as Kakuni Donburi (seasonal fish, red spring onions, ginger, konbu pickle, sous vide quail egg served over sushi rice) and Seasonal Makimono (showcasing traditional maki with creative daily selections) will be available.

Hayashida's culinary prowess has included creating Classic French-inspired cuisine at the Ritz-Carlton Los Angeles, Blowfish San Jose, and Google. He also served on the opening team of Skool in Potrero Hill and launched HayaHon with Johnny Honda, whom he met at Google. HayaHon was in residence at Cafe Royale in the Tendernob and at the 1582 SPACE on Folsom. He also serves as a consulting chef at Southside Spirithouse, the sister venue to John Colins." 

The venue is very small, but it provides a warm and cozy feeling upstairs. We ordered quite a few things and definitely EVERYTHING we got was AMAZING!! I ordered one drink- the ikezo 4 shots for $10 was amazing!!! Super tastey with a bubbly taste mixed in with some sweet chamgpagne or something, but it was amazing!!! The rolls are absolutely to die for and the drinks are perfection. Definitely suggest coming here for any occasion!!! 

price and value: 4/5. We ended up paying $140 after tip and tax. So about $70 per person, we did get 3 drinks each and a few rolls. 

taste: 5/5 We ordered the john collins roll, takoba roll, and giants roll. All were amazing!! We also got sashimi too which just melted in your mouth!! It was perfection.

service: 5/5 loved our server, she gave great recommendation and definitely suggested great drinks and food!!!
author: Amy Y.

description:
I knew I was sittin' next to a soul sistah when the plates arrived and we both grabbed the Japanese sea bass (can't recall the official title, but I shall call it Zentacular, for now), it was a special, we only bought two peices. Black grilling seams scarred the fish, and we both sunk our teeth in at the same time. Pause for dramatic effect. Eyelids sliding open, slow-mo. I look at Julie, she's lookin' back at me, sly grins become teethy smiles. No words needed. Possibly my favorite sushi bite in years.

And the rest was terrific, to boot. Rachel's review mentions that they ditch the fry and aioli mess you'll find most places, totally agreed. The focus of the eats is fresh and flayvahful, seasonal, definitely unique (I believe I encountered some pickled red onion and beets). This is the place I was supposed to visit when I told everyone in Albuquerque I was going to San Francisco. I found it, some of the best sushi of my desert strewn life.

I don't believe I saw signage on the alleyway door alluding to the sushi bar. Oh, how sly of you, Takoba! When I arrived the small 20-seater upstairs dining area was totally packed, but it only took about 20 minutes for the host to text me, seats were available. FYI, keep an eye on your phone, they hold reservations for just five minutes. But the wait was certainly soothed with a cocktail at John Colins Lounge, and the beer and saki selections up in sushi land were super solid. I can't recommend the place enough, and to think, it's right around the corner from headquarters...
author: Howie K.

description: This is a small private sushi joint. It's hidden in the small alley. There is nothing fancy here, but the quality of sushi and presentation is pretty amazing. We ordered Walu nigiri and a special Extra roll. Both were fresh and tasty. Service is friendly but not over the top. Will definitely come back here to try other items on the menu.
author: Ynu G.

description: This sushi joint is very tucked away almost in an alley way and upstairs of a John Colins. There isn't a whole lot of space so definitely not great for large parties. I ordered the 8 piece Sashimi, John Colins, the Minna and Midori roll and a bottle of sake.They were all super fresh and the fish really does melt in your mouth. My only gripe is between two grown adults, this is barely enough food. If I spent over a hundred dollars between two people I would expect my hunger to be satisfied afterwards. My friend and I had to go to the chipotle around the corner afterwards. Overall this is a great place, but don't come here super hungry, you probably won't leave full.
author: Davy L.

description: This restaurant is impossible to find. When we did find it it was the size of a dorm room. I wish I could comment on the quality of the food, but I couldn't eat there because it is 21 and up; which was not formally disclosed on their website.
author: Victoria Z.

description:
Takoba is a bit hard to find if you don't know where it is. It is located on the SECOND FLOOR of John Collins (a bar). There is a small staircase leading to the restaurant on the left when you walk inside John Collins.

We came here at around 8:30pm on a Friday and there was about a 30-45 minute wait. They gave us an option to sit downstairs at John Collins if we didn't want to wait. Since the wait was a bit too long for us, we decided to sit downstairs at John Collins to eat. Thus, I cannot write on the experience of dining at Takoba so I will strictly be reviewing the food only. Also, I personally do not recommend sitting at the bar unless you are really in a rush and/or are looking to eat fast.

We got a spicy tuna roll ($10), a salmon avocado roll ($10), and a spicy tuna hand roll ($8). All 3 rolls were fresh and tasted great. However, for some reason, the rolls didn't fill me up at all. It felt as if I ate air. I have a very small stomach so eating something small fills me up fast, but these rolls didn't fill me up even the slightest bit.

Taking a star off for spending $10 on a roll and not getting full. But I would consider coming back here to wait and properly sit at the restaurant to try out other things on the menu!
author: Jen S.

description: Best sushi I've had in SF so far. I'm so happy we discovered this jewel because I'll be back for lunch and dinner alllllllll the time! The Oban roll was bomb, as was the Walu nigiri (we had 4 orders it was that good).
author: Mariecar M.

description:
Tucked above like a hidden attack, Takoba has unique decor, friendly staff, and a decent amount of seating for a small space.

We were quickly greeted by the waitress as we arrived to the top of the stairs. In the small space, there is a sushi bar to our left, a long wooden table in the middle that separates extra bar seating in front of large framed windows. I like that the decor was simple and followed the "beachy" theme that the bar John Collins captures.
We came in for dinner around 7pm and there was no one there. It was quite loud because of the bar, but we sat closely around the edge of the middle table and enjoyed each others company.The waitress was very attentive and asked us numerous times if we were ready to order or if we needed anything else from the sushi bar. 

We ordered three rolls and sashimi: John Colin's, Minna, Midori and tuna sashimi all which I felt were unique in their own way. The Minna was my favorite for the flavored unagi on top. We also ordered (2) Kirins each that was delivered to us from the bar. If you want to escape from the bar scene and enjoy sushi but still want to enjoy a cup of joy, then this is a the right place to be.
author: Linda K.

description: Atmosphere. It is a great restaurant in a good location. It's as if someone took a cafe of your dreams and would build in your city.
author: Louis B.

description: Hidden little sushi restaurant had excellent quality fish and creative rolls. The seating is mostly at the bar or stools along the window, and the menu is very minimal. But the quality is really good. I got the John Collins roll, which was delicious, as well as a hamachi nigiri roll, which was way better than hamachi I have held elsewhere lately.
author: Mike B.

description:
Good: 
-sushi: delicious.

Bad: 
-cocktails: HORRIBLE. They were undrinkable and $10. Nope. No. Nope. 
- venue: for not cheap sushi, feels a little odd to be in a clubesque setting
- seating: stools are uncomfortable and cramped
author: Hannah P.

description:
A friend had recommended this place to me as a hidden gem above a bar with limited seating. So when we were looking for a quick meal before seeing a movie at the Metreon, we decided to give Takoba SF a try. 

We sat by the window, and I ordered the Takoba chirashi. The waiter didn't really seem to know what fish was in the bowl and got confused when trying to explain what it was. But otherwise, the meal was pleasant, and the decorations (the snake on the ceiling and the blue and white vases) were nice. Also, great for watching people look for the restaurant outside
author: Jenny K.

description:
We came with our family and I'm so happy we did. The spot is small so prepare to wait if there's a lot of people or just get there early. The service is awesome, everyone is so nice and the food comes out really fast. They do try to accommodate you if you have special requests but trust them cause everything is so good. I loved the miso soup and the sushi was beautiful. I tend to hate fish smells but when they were taking the fish out it smelled like ocean water, which made me know the fish was super fresh. 
When you walk into John Colin's just go upstairs and enjoy!
author: Melissa P.

description:
Quality sushi, not a lot of selection but the taste was great and friendly service.

Location was surprising and once we started eating we didn't consider location as a negative
author: Armen K.

description:
Inside John Collins Lounge, up the stairs to a non-descript and basically unadvertisted sushi bar serving up some delicious sashimi and rolls as well a full menu of japanese whisky and sake.  They open right at 5pm and I suggest getting here then or shortly after as even on a Monday night it will fill up. 

Perfect place to hit for some pre-Giants game sushi for an hour and a half before you head down to the stadium for some baseball action.
author: Chad T.

description: Stupid place... joined the waitlist just to show up just for them to say it's only a suggestion and they could not accommodate our party of 4. Lame stupid and ridicules.
author: Brian H.

description: Funky little spot with friendly staff. will come back for whole tapas experience.
author: S K.

description: I discovered Takoba SF on Yelp and decided to give it a try.  It's a small little sushi bar above an actual bar but the staff is lovely and the sushi is delicious.  I asked for some sushi recommendations and was delighted by the choices and their incredible flavor!  Miso soup was good, too.  They don't serve green or any other hot tea, which seemed weird but the cocktail I had was yummy.  I'll be back!
author: Gerald K.

description: This place is amazing! It's super tiny but very lively. The sushi is amazing. They have awesome hand rolls that are very tasty, highly recommend them!
author: Antonio H.

description: Best sushi spot in the city! Super fresh and delicious. Favourite Roll is the Minna Roll. The place is very tiny so be prepared to wait at least 30-45 minutes to be seated. Definitely worth it though!
author: Ghazal S.

description:
I heard about this place from one of my coworkers and how incredible the sushi is here (if you're lucky enough to snag a space without waiting for long). My friend happened to be visiting and I jumped at the chance to try this place out on a rainy Monday night. 

Surprisingly, there were still seats available at 5:30 PM and my friend and I got seated right away (they do require that the entire party is there since there aren't many seats). Everything looked good on the menu, but we ordered the Takoba and the John Collins rolls since those are two of the most popular rolls according to one of the waitresses.

The Takoba was nice--the spicy tuna along with the regular salmon and tuna on top with the jalapeno cilantro aioli made for a nice cohesive bite.

I didn't get to try the John Collins despite our initial plans to share, so I'm just going off of one roll here. The one roll I had was pretty good, but not as mindblowing as I thought it would be. I would still come back again (I just don't know if I'd wait half an hour like some people seem to have had to do).

If you do go, try to get to the place early and look for the stairs on your left when you enter John Collins. I'm guessing it was just the rain the day I went that kept the place only somewhat packed, so plan on it being pretty busy!
author: Patrick L.

description: I am so impressed of this restaurant. Ordered the chirashi, and the rice blown me away! It has perfect moisture, and a natural taste of sweetness, I really wonder how they made the rice taste sweet and feels natural. Also the mushroom in the miso, the ginger taste perfect. I can really tell the owner focus a lot on the details. Keep up, please.
author: Kelvin Y.

description:
This is an adorable hidden little sushi bar inside John Collins lounge. And I'm not kidding when I say hidden! Based off the Yelp photos, their thing might be rolls but I'm more of a sashimi and nigiri girl.

I ordered the sashimi platter (8 pieces for $18) and the ahi tuna hand roll. All of the fish was super fresh, delicious and melt-in-your-mouth. It was a little pricy and selection for nigiri and sashimi was limited but what they had was good.

I love how tiny and hole-in-the-wall it is and would definitely come back!
author: Ninette C.

description:
05.13.16

I've been going to John Colins for years. To the point where I made friends with the bouncer. (Is that sad?)

I'm so glad Takoba found a permanent spot instead of just serving their sushi alongside the drinks. Now I get to go upstairs, sit down, watch the crowd at the bar and hold a conversation without shouting every other phrase.

Plus, they bring the cocktails up to you! Fantastic addition. Well done, JC!

Total damage for two: $70
author: Jenny L.

description: If you come here, buckle down and commit.  What I mean is don't give a shit about what everything costs....order the nigiri sampler, try the 5 different fish, and then order more of whatever you like.  This is also one of the few places out of 1009043 where I actually think the juice is worth the squeeze of ordering rolls.  TRY THE ROLLS THEY ROCK.  Seating sucks and high chance you'll have to wait.
author: Vince L.

description: Truly extraordinary! A hidden gem of a speakeasy sushi bar located above Tom Collins.  I was an exchange student in Japan, and this is the best sushi I've had in the U.S.
author: Dylan W.

description: I would say that I didn't have a refined taste in sushi because they all tasted the same to me. But I think it's because I never had good quality sushi. The sushi rolls at Takoba were so amazing and fresh that all other sushi I had do not compare at all! The presentation was A+! The drinks there were also soooo good. I got the Jon Chu Hi, and it tasted just like pineapple juice.
author: Annie C.

description:
I wasn't going to review this place because I didn't want the word to get out, but when I read "Stefany Z's" silly little rant below, I just couldn't help myself. 

No Stefy, there is no cooked sushi.  Put your big boy pants on and eat sushi the way it's meant to be consumed - RAW.  

As EVERYONE has mentioned, they do not take reservations so if you show up at prime time, yes, you are going to put your name on a list and wait.  Pretty unfair of you to ding them for your 30-minute wait.

And yes, it's small and every review mentions that, so why the surprise?  God you're annoying.  

The sushi always exceeds my expectations and the staff is totally friendly and awesome and attentive.  It can get loud when it's packed so use common sense and don't schedule an important business meeting.  But is it fun to go with your friends?  Yeah totally... it's a super great spot.
author: Ted T.

description:
This might be the best sushi I've had in the city so far. Might judgement might be impaired by the alcohol I had downstairs in John Collins, but given that Takoba is tucked away right above the bar and there is no reservations, I consider pregaming with some mixed drinks to be part of the Takoba experience. 

I got here around 7 and put my name down. The lady said that there'd be an hour to an hour and a half long wait but it turned out to be closer to 45 minutes. There's seating for less than 20 people so it's a little cramped but the wait and lack of space are well worth it. The assortment of nigiri and sashimi that my friend and I collectively ordered were delicious and absolutely melted in my mouth. The miso soup had mushrooms in it and tasted "meatier" than any miso soup I've had. The sake selection was extensive and the nigori we chose delicious. It was a very fun very delicious experience and I would love to come back to Takoba sometime. Little hidden gem in the city- wish I had known about it sooner!
author: Philip W.

description: BEST SUSHI EVER! This was the only sushi place we tried while in San Francisco, but it was the best choice we could have ever made! To be honest, it took us about 30 mins walking around trying to find where this restaurant was after asking 3 different people, so I gave 4 stars for there not being a noticeable sign. It's located on the second floor in the John Collin's restaurant. Very intimate/small setting, so not a good place for groups larger than 4 people. Atmosphere is very chill. The John Collin's Roll was our favorite!
author: Nori S.

description:
I've been here twice now and I can definitely see myself coming back again. The restaurant itself is really really small, can only seat maybe 20-30 people at a time so I would not recommend coming her with more than a group of 2-3 people. You're sitting around essentially benches, so you'll have to be okay with "sharing the table" but it's still quite easy to get privacy. Since the place is really small, try to come here outside of the normal rush hours (come before 6pm for example) because the wait is quite long otherwise

The waiters here are really nice, but there is a slight lack of coordination. The second time I came, we were asked if we wanted to get any drinks by three different people within our first couple minutes of sitting down. 

I'm a fan of the sushi here, it's not your typical sushi combinations and flavors. I got the John Collins roll and it was one of the more unique combinations for sushi that I've had in the city. I got 8 moderately sized pieces for $13 which isn't too bad for SF.
author: Cassie Z.

description: Smaller menu. Hard to find. Very small dining room. Service was slow and relatively disconnected. Can't say there was anything special but it was good sushi.
author: Walter L.

description: This is my secret sushi spot that is no longer a secret.  Tucked away in the loft area above a bar, you'll find one of the higher quality, reasonably priced sushi spots in all of FiDi.  The nigiri sushi as well as the hand rolls here are both awesome (they use tons of real crab in the California hand roll.  I've also yet to order a signature roll that I haven't liked, and I think I've ordered them all.  This spot is small but fun / intimate, and the servers are busy but always polite.
author: Tom G.

description: I ordered a hamachi hand roll and a tuna hand roll. Added avocado to both. I enjoyed with soy and extra wasabi on every bite. Very fresh and delicious. Fair pricing for the city as well. I'll definitely drop back in for lunch. Minus one star because they don't offer miso soup during their day hours. To me, sushi just isn't the same without a warm miso.
author: Laurel A.

description: This restaurant advertises no where that you have to be 21 to eat here. That is unfair especially when I had no intentions of even trying to order alcohol. This restaurant is only looking for people of a certain look so if you aren't it don't bother. It's probably illegal to refuse someone service for food unless you were seated at the bar. And of course, I had no intention of doing so.
author: Bianca B.

description: I almost don't want to leave a review because I want to keep this place a secret so it won't get so crowded. But after trying 10-15 sushi places in the city and being born to sushi loving Japanese parents, I have to say this is hands down the best sushi in the city. The quality of the fish is a huge deal to me and Takoba is consistently fresh, buttery, and just of noticeably high quality. The only downsides to this place is 1) it's expensive to get full and 2) it's cramped and often there's a wait. But so worth it!
author: Christine D.

description:
What a fun novelty: it's a sushi bar inside of a regular bar (which is also a coffee shop by day, whoa!). On one hand, everything here is pretty overpriced (otherwise I'd give 5 stars). On the other hand, it's convenient and delicious and charming.

The sushi bar itself is really tiny, but you can order from the sushi menu at any of the tables in John Collins downstairs, so it's not as hard to find a place to sit most weekday nights. And even though it's in a bar, it's actually really good sushi! The options are fairly limited but they're all quite fresh and delicious. I especially enjoy the handrolls, which feature your fish of choice and are $6 apiece. Portions are pretty small so don't come super hungry (or be prepared to spend a lot of money). 

I find it super strange to be at a place that serves sushi and not hot tea, but I guess it's technically inside a bar... That being said, John Collins drinks are pretty great, and hipster alcohol and sushi makes for a fun mix. Great for a night out with friends when you want to satisfy your craving for a good cocktail and great sushi at the same time!
author: Brittany C.

description: Best. Sake. Chriashi. Bowl. Of. My. Life. The upstairs restaurant seating is small and limited but they serve food anywhere in the bar. It's a great atmosphere that feels spacious with the high ceiling loft-like interior.
author: Sora M.

description: My friend and I have different views about this place. The rolls are yum . If you are looking for a place to enjoy some sushi roll and beer talk with your friends , this is the place ! For me the food is not authentic more like Americanized sushi and the place is tiny. Too crowded and loud to have good conversation.
author: Jiani S.

description: The food was very fresh but it was a bit too loud for me.  Also,  I have to say it was a bit expensive for the amount of food.  However, if you don't mind the price, you should try it.
author: Wendy J.

description: Excellent sushi highly recommend and the girls servers are very friendly and provide excellent service. Very small place so not very accommodating but def worth trying. Unfortunately the drinks come from the bar below (Tom Collins) and don't measure up to the great food. Well the four drinks I tried anyway.
author: Tony C.

description:
Such a cute little place to grab food and drinks afterwards. If you get a seat by the window, you can people watch while chatting away!

I absolutely love the ambiance of Takoba. It's a little active and boisterous from the lounge downstairs, but the area itself is brightly lit and really open. It's a great place to catch up with friends. The food itself is quite good (although there are certainly better sushi places in the area), and the drinks aren't bad either! I'd definitely come back for both.
author: Jessie Y.

description: Really cool place with fresh, yummy sushi - interesting combinations.  Had the John Collins and Midori. Was so happy to find this place! Got take out but it was in a cool hotel and I would've loved to get a drink at the hotel bar downstairs afterwards had I not gotten take out.
author: Marissa S.

description: Cute place. I wish I looked more closely at the chirashi menu as there was an option to customize it!
author: V H.

description:
This is definitely my favorite sushi bar in SF so far! You really have to search for it to find it but it is so worth the effort. First you'll have to enter a different bar where you will find a stairs that will take you to this great place. 
It's a small sushi bar where they pay a lot of attention to your food and hospitality. The ambiance is great, the place is well decorated and the team is very nice. 
It's a definite "must go to" if you're a sushi addict!
author: Bruce B.

description:
This speak easy (easy speak?...I really should learn the right term by now) sushi spot is a hidden gem upstairs of John Colins.    It is very small and tucked away upstairs, but on a weeknight there wasn't a wait.  We did, however, want to sit at the window so there was a small wait for that to open up.  So... sorry, I lied a little about the wait time.

Dinner: The Minna & John Colins...basically cause the guy next to us ordered it and it looked so good, we wanted it too!  There aren't too many options on the menu, but what they have is good.  We had a friendly waitress and nice seats with an awesome view for our meal.  I liked this secret spot.
author: Lyn C.

description:
Takoba is a super cute hidden gem inside John Collins. There aren't a lot of affordable, good sushi options in this part of town and I was very surprised to find Takoba.

The choices are somewhat limited but the options are all solid. Is it the best sushi I've ever had? Absolutely not! But it hits the spot and my wallet still feels ok after I leave.
author: Yi Z.

description: Nice Sishi but horrible seats and the space is tooooo small - the size of my bathroom! It's, in some way, disrespectful to sit customers so closely next to each other in such a small space. Didn't enjoy seating next to other people and listening to their talks...
author: Alisa K.

description: Had a quick dinner at Takoba SF. I love their sushi! It tasted very fresh. The restaurant is located on the second floor of bar, which was a little bit difficult to find for the first time, but shouldn't be a big problem. It's a small place, but not crowded. 1 star minus for the construction going on outside the window, everything else was great! :)
author: Jessika Y.

description: Best sushi ever. I was in town alone and stopped by to treat myself, debating going back just to eat here again. I had no wait at all but I was by myself. Amazing spot with amazing sushi.
author: Ashlyn G.

description: Hands down the best sushi restaurant in the world. And I've been to a bunch of sushi restaurants.  I've traveled extensively around Japan and dined at some of the best restaurants in the country and I would say that the sushi at Takoba is tastier!  I love this place!!!!
author: Mason W.

description:
This place is the epitome of a hidden gem. You literally have to find this place before you can even sit down. It is a sushi restaurant located inside a bar. I don't know who thought that was a good idea, but I am not complaining. Since you have to enter into the bar then take stairs up to it, I would not recommend any large parties because they are like 10 seats up there.

I think we ordered every roll just to try them out. They were pretty good, but nothing too out of the ordinary. If you are expecting some crazy and different rolls, this isn't the place for you. It is more of a simple and tradition type of food setting. The service is really quick for both drinks and food. If you order an alcoholic beverage it is made downstairs so the server can bring it to you instead of waiting in a hectic bar line.

This place would be a great place to go for a quick snack and drink before you meet up with your friends for a real dinner. It is a cool spot, but I wouldn't recommend it for date night because the music from the bar is really loud and I could barely hear myself speaking.
author: Theo T.

description: The sushi and the people here are amazing. Great vibe. The sushi chef recommended I try the Walu. It was AMAZING - don't leave without trying it!
author: Julie S.

description:
I've been there on Thursday around 6pm and the place was really packed. I have to admit that they have one of the best sushi in town.
I will definitely give it a visit it again and order the sushi roll.
author: Ali A.

description:
Another Hard to find amazing restaurant. I love hidden restaurants with good food. :)

We decided that we felt like having some sushi tonight and thankfully found this place on Yelp. Finding this place in person was a little harder. As the address here on Yelp says it is inside the John Collins lounge on Minna street, upstairs to be precise. We could not find any markings outside for it though. It does not have a lot of seating space but would work well for a small group. 

The sushi was very good. My favorite was the Special Xtra roll, followed by the John Collins roll and then the Minna roll. I would definitely go back for the sushi. 

They have a very nice selection of single malts and whiskey. The biggest surprise for me on the drinks front was that they have Deschutes stout on tap.
