I and the server had a big laugh when I told them that we were from Portland and love this beer. My friend from the Bay Area tried it and I ended up having a nice Japanese whiskey. 

Enjoy good sushi and a relaxing drink here.
author: Nipun S.

description: It's sad for me to write this review because this place was good and was one of my favorite sushi roll restaurants in SF until we got sick eating there last night.  I felt nauseous and clammy shortly after eating 3 rolls (Minna, Oban, Spicy Hamachi).  This time, we sat downstairs in the dark room with the large TV screen and weren't able to see what we were eating.  I guess it was never a good idea to eat sushi in the dark-- maybe we could've seen the sushi not looking so fresh and sent them back.  Anyway, I hope this won't evolve into full blown food poisoning or parasitic infection-- basically my worst fear after eating sushi!
author: Apple M.

description: Hands down the best sushi joints in SF! Amazing place not big on space but a hidden gem in SF's sushi scene. It was the first time everything I tried , which essentially was the entire menu, was perfect. To compare the caliber of food here, the sushi quality was only second to some of the finest sushi places I've been to in Tokyo.  Overall I can not recommend a better place in SF, six stars all around. Hope they keep doing their thing here, because it's no doubt going to lead to success.
author: Mike I.

description: Best sushi in the city! It was kind of difficult to find. You have to go through a bar called John Colin's and go up the stairs. It's very small and it may take a while to get in but so worth it! The cocktails are good, too!
author: Samantha M.

description: Small and a nice place with good quality sushis. A bit expensive, the miso soup in particular at 6$ I thought was too much for what it was. Too bad the avocado wasn't ripened enough it made the sushi less tasty.
author: Valentine H.

description: This place has some of the best (and freshest) sushi I've ever had. The upstairs is tiny and always has a wait. That's why I love that they serve their sushi menu downstairs where there is plenty of room and rarely a wait. Their cocktails aren't my favorite, but between the delicious sushi and sashimi, I don't even care!
author: Amanda Claire K.

description:
I've been to John Collins a few times now, and I had no idea there was a sushi restaurant upstairs!

Tucked inside of John Collins (you won't find it on the street!), Takoba serves only sushi and sashimi, but they do it well!

Ordered the John Collins and a salmon handroll, and was not disappointed.
The rolls are on the small side - 5 pieces, but the quality was amazing.

If you're looking for a bite to eat in a cute venue, Takoba is a great option!
author: Michelle L.

description: Tiny tiny restaurant space but amazing sushi. A little bit less bang for your buck than you would want but delicious none the less. Also the bar was fantastic and everyone was mi
author: Molli W.

description: Legit sushi. So good. It is a small space and you have to walk In the coffee shop and turn left, then go upstairs. Definitely give it a try!
author: Kate C.

description:
4 stars for the value!  the girls came here on monday night at 7:15 and it was surprisingly packed!  supposed to be a hidden gem right?  personally my favorite part of takoba is that the drinks are from john colins - dark n stormy anyone?! YES.  you can also order sushi at the bar downstairs and eat on the 'dance floor' where they set up a couple large high tops for early evening feasting.  i assume they will remove the tables when it gets crowded.  

we ordered 4 rolls - special xtra, minna, john colins, tuna poke.  they were all pretty good - great fish to rice ratio (more protein less carbs!) and pretty good flavor.  i would totally get take out here.  dinner for 3 with drinks - $40 pp after tax n tip. not bad at all!
author: Christina L.

description:
"The files are INSIDE the computer?" -Zoolander

"The sushi joint is INSIDE of the bar?" -me

What we have here, ladies and gentlemen, is some serious biz on biz action. Takoba is tucked away, hiding upstairs *in* John Colins Lounge.

With only 23 reviews, Yelp Detroit and I felt like we had stumbled upon a secret sushi jackpot. Cha-ching!

I mean, 23 reviews for a five-star spot in SF? Get outta town. (I mean, that means Yelp's got us living even better than the locals if you really think about it... )

As other reviewers have noted, the sushi is fresh. The rolls are delicious, well-composed and without all that fry and aioli. The salmon sashimi practically melted in my mouth.

Attentive service and a lovely atmosphere despite the space being slightly small.

Five stars, would return. This is some damn fine sushi, people!
author: Rachel F.

description: One of the best sushi roll restaurants in san francisco with always-fresh and delicious fish and flavorful bites.  Very reasonable prices too.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
author: Max S.

description: Amazing, little sushi place!! The food was excellent and they have a good happy hour menu. It was hard to find, but totally worth the hunt! Just call, if you get lost. ;)
author: Heather R.

description:
I had this place bookmarked for quite a long time. Decided to finally give it a visit after a happy hour in downtown SF. Firstly, yeah I admit, it's cool that this sushi bar is on top of a bar. Like sure, they have that going for them... But overall, I didn't like it and I won't be coming back.

Food:
They don't have cooked sushi. So if you don't like to eat raw sushi, nor like it, this is not the place for you. I repeat, they do not offer cooked sushi. I was so disappointed because that's all I eat. That's not the only reason as to why I'm giving this place 2 stars. It's also crazy expensive for the quality/amount of sushi you receive. 

Service:
Sloooow. This place seems like it's always packed, so don't expect to get seated right away. We had to wait about half an hour, at this point we decided we'd get more drinks and my hunger had faded away.  They also didn't fill up our glasses of water, even though it was burning hot. Again, not the sushi bar's fault, but just a heads up for you people with drunken hunger. 

Atmosphere:
It's sooo hot up here. It's packed, hot, and a small enclosed space. I was literally brushing elbow to elbow with the person next to me. Not a great place to enjoy dinner if you're a claustrophobic like I am! It was also incredibly loud so you can't really hold a conversation without guessing what the person next to you just said. Sadly, I was dissapointed by Takoba.
author: Stefany Z.

description:
Yes yes...another 5 star sushi review in San Francisco.  This place is unique and amazing.

Like every mentions, it is tucked away inside of John Collins, and doesn't have a lot of seating space, but you don't normally have trouble getting a seat if your party is small.

They have their own cocktails made downstairs, and an assortment of unique and delicious sushi rolls.  My favorite would definitely be the Minna roll.  So good.

This is a perfect little romantic date spot.
author: John H.

description: Some of the best Sushi I've ever had!!  The place is a little tricky to find, but my girlfriend and I were able to walk in on a Saturday night and enjoy this amazing little spot.  Highly recommend
author: Joe R.

description:
A hidden gem tucked away on top of a popular bar.
The ambience is fun and lively, service is quick and efficient, food is great quality for the price point.

We got 3 rolls (Oban, spicy hamachi, and the salmon) between the two of us and we were able to comfortably finish everything. The Oban was definitely our favorite followed by the hamachi and then the salmon.

We were blessed by a really short wait time but I can totally see people waiting 45+ minutes if they came at a busy time.

Definitely would be back for and off-peak hour treat!
author: Samuel P.

description: Excellent chirashi bowls! That's all that was on the menu, and there's not really a sign, exactly, and it's daytime use (along with a coffee concession) of a bar. Super food, though!
author: Chris D.

description:
It's a speakeasy style sushi joint!  As other reviewers said, the sushi is a tiny bit pricier & smaller portioned than a standard family-owned sushi place to be found on every corner of SF, but worth it for the ambiance.

San Francisco Giants roll:  Had a nice smokey flavor to it

Tuna poke role:  Cool concept, a standard avocado roll covered in tuna poke, which made it a fun eating experience.
author: Sona P.

description: AMAZING! The rolls are unique (coffee sauce..whaaaa) and so delicious. Seriously pick anything off the menu and you'll be happy. The restaurant is TINY but you can order at the bar on the first floor so that helps a lot. The staff at the bar is super nice. Prices are reasonable.
author: Melanie L.

description: Lovely hidden gem! Excellent rolls, very fresh and flavorful. Our favorite was the John Collins. Cocktails were good as well. Great service!
author: Jenelle C.

description: This was such a cute little sushi place. They are renovating outside so it's hard to find because it's upstairs with a bar as the entrance. I'm giving it 4 stars just because it was a little confusing and there isn't a way to understand where to go or if you're in the right place until you're basically seated. The rolls were great though! Wish there were more options for appetizers but it's a small place so it makes sense they don't have much room for prep.
author: Lauren T.

description: Takoba is a small little sushi restaurant that overlooks a bar. Came here about a month ago and though the menu and venue are both small, the fish is super fresh and yummy!! It was definitely an experience enjoying my sushi while looking at the drunken dancers below. Since it was atop a bar, they had the whole specialty cocktails menu and those were awesome as well. The sushi chefs in the back work pretty efficiently and, true to some of the reviews here, scored some free fresh nigiri to try!
author: Wing L.

description: Super small sushi restaurant inside a bar (John Colins). It's located upstairs once you come in. There's most likely a wait since it's small, but no worries because you can order and eat downstairs at the bar! John Colins roll is pretty good ($13) but not filling. California Roll is $11 here, so this place doesn't have the nicest prices for the small serving sizes...
author: Annie S.

description:
This place is a hidden gem on the mezzanine level of John Collins, seats maybe 15 people max so be prepared for a wait. We were quoted at least an hour wait for a party of 4, which we totally expected at 8pm on a Friday night. So we wandered over to one of the other bars nearby to wait out or time with a cocktail.

After 20 minutes, I got a call that our table was ready. Fastest hour ever - so we chugged our drinks and headed back. We ordered about 8 rolls and a bottle of sake (not on the menu so make sure to ask), it came to about $40 a person, which is a great deal for tasty sushi roll that we prepared quickly but honestly, could have been rolled a little tighter, mine kept falling apart.
author: Sarah S.

description: I almost do not want to review this place, given how much I want it to stay a hidden gem! I had a chance to grab a dinner here with a friend and we both really enjoyed our experience! We got 3 different rolls and despite being slightly on the pricy side, we felt like the quality and quantity were fair. The rolls vary from your standard California to drink inspired Tom Collins rolls. The only gripe I have with this place is how it only holds around 15 people! Overall I would definitely come back!
author: Greg B.

description: Secret restaurants are the best restaurants!  I ate there for lunch, really good sushi. Get there early if you can.
author: Paul B.

description: Small, cramped...poor management of waiting individuals, no appt system.  I wish I could have experienced better.
author: Hiromi N.

description: Arrived on a Thursday night. Was illegally refused service because of my service animal by Gwendolee, the head of staff. Please also note that this restaurant also does not have wheelchair access in violation of the ADA
author: Karen N.

description: Absolutely the definition of a hidden gem! I think Takoba is now one of, if not my favorite, sushi spots in the city. Yes it's small, but it quite literally epitomizes the idea of a sushi bar and you know everything you try is going to be really fresh and delicious. The atmosphere is so great and spot on for a date - grab a drink downstairs in John Collins if there's a wait - if not, head upstairs and get ready to be cozy and have some of the freshest sushi around. Our waitress was super attentive and fun, relaxed, and knowledgeable about the menu which was helpful when trying to narrow down which special on the menu we wanted. My friend and I had the Tuna Poke roll, the tempura shrimp, salmon crunch, and the John Collins roll. Everything we tried was incredible and left us happy & full. I will definitely be going back - so yummy!
author: Frankie I.

description: This, friends, is why you eat sushi. Skip the fancy rolls - you want fish this great to shine through. Chirashi bowl: one thing better than the next. Walu sushi: possibly best ever. Oh, and don't drown it in soy and wasabi either. It's splendid fish, expertly prepared. Just come here and eat the sushi. That is all.
author: Ann D.

description: Was visiting SF and got takeout from here.  So crazy good!!  Both the rolls that I got were insanely delicious and fresh tasting.  Made me wish I didn't have dinner plans other nights so I could come back.  Ordered online for takeout, and everything went smoothly.  Food was ready exactly when promised.
author: Diana H.

description: Excellent sushi and sashimi little restaurant. Located on top of John Collins bar. Food was great and good drinks (from downstairs). The space is tiny, but service makes up for it.
author: Carlos V.

description: Great restaurant. Small so I wouldn't recommend groups. The hand roll was to die for!
author: Ayo S.

description:
This is probably the best sushis I had in the city.
It is a tiny restaurant, they only have a few tables and one can not reserve so you will have wait. Thought the wait is never terrible during the week.

Would be amazing if it was open for lunch but it is not.

Would be a great date spot if you did not feel pressure to leave your table for people waiting on the stairs.
author: Jr P.

description: Wow. I was ready to doubt the yelp reviews as i travel extensively including Asia and i was not expecting anything special. How this place pulls off such high quality food in this miniscule place ishard to fathom. Chef's special sashimi had awesome salmon and tuna and amberjack and the salmon avocado roll ( something i would normally never order) was superb. Even the gari was exceptional.
author: Dan S.

description: Delicious. Fresh. Tricky to find inside and around the corner then up the stairs but worth it. Convenient ordering online and takeout. Fairly small portions left me wishing I'd ordered one more roll...
author: Shaun S.

description: Sushi was decent! My favorite was the Giants roll. My only complain is that there is hardly any seating here. We had to sit down on one of the tables on the lower level, which would have been ok, but the DJ wasn't good.
author: Rachelle B.

description:
Hidden sushi bar on a side-street, inside of a divey-looking bar.  Pretty cool.

Not many tables either - get here early.

Service was nice, decor was OK.  The food is where this place shines.  We had the red crab roll (excellent), the takoba roll (excellent) and the poke roll (really excellent).

Really great sushi.  Come check it out.
author: Jason H.

description: This place was great!  Small space as part of a bar/lounge below. Food was FANTASTIC. Smaller menu than a lot of sushi places, but great flavor. I would definitely come back here again.
author: Kelsey P.

description: Great sushi.  Good staff. Busy place and okay prices.  Went at dinner time.  Prettt loud place but very happening.
author: Matt H.

description:
Really enjoyed my meal here! We ordered the John Collins, the Takoba roll and the minna. I loved the John Collins and the Takoba - I highly recommend trying these two. 

Overall, the first floor is a nice bar which gets pretty crowded Thursday nights. It's a fun atmosphere- perfect for pre dinner drinks. 

The actual restaurant has family style seating and gets a little loud, but otherwise a nice experience!
author: Michelle L.

description: Are you kidding me with these reviews? The place is a closet, the sushi was average and the service was the worst I've experienced in a long time. The guy sitting next to me ordered a roll and sat there for 30 minutes waiting and still didn't get it when I finally got up and walked to the cashier to get my check. Who reviews these places?
author: Jeff H.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night around 8pm, and the wait was estimated at 45 minutes. Ended up only being 20! They'll give your cell a ring, so you can wander around or just grab some drinks downstairs. The space is amazing, really hip and cozy upstairs from John Collins. There are some bar seats by the sushi chefs, a big communal table, and some bar seats at the window. The seats facing out the window have a great people-watching vantage point, as it looks directly onto the street below. 

When we sat down, I was really hoping the food would match the ambiance -- and the chefs did not disappoint. 
- Yellowtail sashimi - so good, some of the freshest yellowtail I've ever had
- Walu sashimi - comes seared, which brings out the flavors and makes it taste smokey/fatty
- Salmon sashimi - great, though not as mind-blowing as the first two 
- Seabass sashimi - special of the day. Not always a fan of seabass sashimi, but this just melted in my mouth

In addition, we had the Minna roll and the tuna tartare. Both were sizable, tasty, and super fresh. Overall, check came out to ~$30 per person with tip. Am already planning my return here!
author: Christine H.

description: I was pretty excited based on the 4.5 rating, but I can't remember a time I was more let down by a sushi restaurant. We ordered four special rolls and they all basically tasted the same, partially because the fish was cut so thinly you couldn't really taste it. Rice was undercooked. Sauces were bland. I'd honestly put this in the same category as grocery store sushi. I consider putting ginger on sushi to be a sin, but it's basically your only choice if you want flavor in your roll from this place.
author: Will O.

description: Best sushi in the city! The ingredients are incredibly fresh and the staff is top notch. Sometimes there is a bit of a wait for a table, but I think it is worth it for the quality that you're getting. Yum!
author: Heather N.

description: The freshest sushi I've had in the city. Only open Monday - Friday, and expect at least a 45 minute wait. I suggest grabbing a happy hour drink downstairs at John Collins while waiting. It's a tiny little place  overlooking the alleyway, but I've been here 6 times now and have never been disappointed. Skip the rolls and order multiples of the freshest nigiri around!
author: Stephanie A.

description: Fantastic find! A little cozy for sure but great spot. Sushi was delicious, few choices but all great. Rolls were very good, Giants roll and john Collins rolls were both winners. My new go to place in SF! A bit hot as it upstairs in a loft setting and be prepared to wait for a spot.
author: Brad M.

description: Hidden gem in SOMA. Their fish us one of the freshest in this area and it's good for lunch on a weekday if you work in this area. But it gets full really quick so you want to be there before 12.
author: Helena H.

description: The venue is small and the wait is long even for weekdays. They tell you your wait is about 90 minutes and people would immediately turn away. But we ended up waiting for ~30 minutes. The rolls were quite Americanized as the fish covered on top were seasoned much like poke. Their draft beer was pretty nice, the food was tasty, the venue was cozy. It does get a little noisy with people drinking.
author: Melissa H.

description: Takoba is just about as hole-in-the-wall as you can get, located in the upstairs loft of John Colins Lounge. Somehow they fit a classy, trendy sushi joint above the frenzy of the bar downstairs. My boyfriend and I managed to snag a table on a Friday night, and started off with a few drinks from the bar. Everything is very focused on the alcohol, with not a lot of frills or sugary additions. We tried the Minna Roll and the Takoba Roll, both of which had extremely fresh fish and the perfect blend of extra ingredients. Their more basic rolls, like the salmon avocado, are equally as good and focus on the quality of the fish. SF continues to surprise me with hidden gems like Takoba that really define the food scene!
author: Ashley T.

description:
While it's cool that Takoba is hidden within John Collins bar, it pays for it with cramped space and uncomfortable bar stools. 

The rolls are also pricey for the amount you get. I know sushi is usually expensive anyways but the rolls here are average and tinier than most sushi joints. We were still hungry after getting 3 rolls between 2 people here. There are numerous other sushi places in the area that have better food with comfort. Skip this place if you know what good sushi tastes like.
author: Venus L.

description: This is my favorite sushi place in all of SF. For the quality & price, you can't beat it. I almost don't want to rate it so high because it seems relatively  under the radar for now, but I absolutely love it. Hidden away at the top of john collins, it is a small space so get there early as it fills up. my only complaint is it gets so warm up there! get there early and sit at the little window nook seat!
author: Shelby S.

description:
Generally poor service throughout the night which was really disappointing. When we checked in we were told our table would be ready in 15 minutes and that we could wait downstairs and grab a drink. After about 25 minutes and not receiving s call as promised I went up to check.  The same receptionist we checked in with asked if we had checked in? She must have been really out of it. 

Finally after being seated and waiting another 15 minutes we ordered. Half our order came out and the rolls were okay, nothing great. We had also ordered the chirashi. The waitress kept telling us every 10 minutes that the bowls would be out. After she did this three times they finally came. To my disappointment they only had 4 pieces of fish. Compared to a roll which is cheaper it was incredibly small and not very special.  

I don't think I'll be back. Average Sushi, cramped space, long wait .
author: Shomik C.

description: John Collins roll is so tasty! This place is TINY (maybe 10 seats?) but nice, relaxed and intimate. We would come back.
author: Tameka S.

description: Really good sushi rolls although somewhat limited fish selection.  But no matter, the cozy (*ahem* cramped) space is actually very cool and lively.  And the fact that you need to enter through a club with no sign for Takoba makes you feel like you're in on the secret.
author: Matthew K.

description:
The waitstaff seemed a little apathetic, but they certainly weren't rude. It's nice, large and clean (albeit kind of a slippery/greasy floor near the kitchen when heading to the restrooms), and the food tastes decent. So, why 2 stars? I got sick.

I ordered a bento box lunch special, along with several pieces of nigiri sushi. About an hour and a half later, I felt very sick to my stomach. I was nauseated and felt clammy, and my BART ride home nearly made me puke out whatever it was I ate. 

Maybe it was a one-time thing, but an experience like this, especially for a first time, makes or breaks a potential repeat customer. I don't think I'll be going back.
author: Marc F.

description: Great little place hidden upstairs above a bar. Fantastic sushi and helpful and friendly staff. Just get there early to avoid the wait (which isn't all that bad in the bar downstairs).
author: Rob P.

description: Really amazing, missed good sushi having moved to Texas.
author: Brendan L.

description: Great spot above John Collin's - hidden gem! Sushi is good, not too expensive, and the place is small and fun. There's probably only seating for less than 20 people, but seems that so few people know about it, the wait normally isn't too bad (especially if you only have 2 or 3 people). The first time I went, I was told it'd be an hour and a half, but only ended up taking 20 minutes. The second time, I walked right in and sat down.
author: Derrick S.

description: I kind of want to keep this place a secret. I had been to John Collins 937492924 times and was SHOCKED to hear there is a sushi place hidden upstairs. Low and behold, my friend wasn't lying to me. Takoba has a limited menu, but the rolls are filling and the sushi are good quality. It's a small space, so there can be a wait, but you can always grab a drink at the bar downstairs before your table is ready. Definitely will be back!
author: Vinitha R.

description: If you are looking for exceptional sushi served  in a cozy setting, this is the place. Outstanding!
author: Lavelle G.

description: thank you yelp. you lead us here. such a cool location; super cozy almost loft style above the bar. best tuna sashimi i have ever had. i dont crave sushi much but my bf loves it and he said it was "really good"
author: Liz T.

description: I love the sushi here. Always tastes fresh and I always recommend this place to my coworkers when we're in sfo. I try a different thing every time I'm here and have yet to have anything I don't absolutely love.
author: Colleen C.

description:
Part of me hates that I am writing this review. In fact, that part of me (let's call him Snarlin' V) made his views known when I checked in last week and saw no reviews for Takoba. He spoke to me in a harsh, actually-louder-than-normal-speech whisper, because that is how he communicates:

SV: Don't you DARE write a review for this place.

V: Really? I think I should. People--

SV: Forget PEOPLE! There are BARELY twenty seats in this tiny-mezzanine-level sushi spot hidden above John Colins. Do you KNOW what will happen if you spill the sashimi on this place? You'll NEVER get a table again. Do I have to remind you about the ahi poke tossed in sesame oil, CRISPY shallots and furikake, and served atop four maki rolls?

V: Why are you talking like this? This seems a little forced-

SV: Don't do THIS Vivek.

Yes, there are only a handful of seats; four at the bar, a few at the window, and a table that we can dub 'communal' since it takes up most of this bunker-sized space. With the din of the bar below wafting up to the balcony -- and the dim lighting -- Takoba is a perfect date spot. It's a little spendy but not crazy. Don't bring a group -- in fact don't go at all. I want this spot all to myself.

Obligatory Title Pun: Make every day TAKO Tuesday.

Menu Readability: Simple narrow card in web fonts. Specials are named after hyperlocal place-lies like Special Xtra and The Minna.

Need to mention: Look up! An impressive octopus mural demands your attention.

What this place teaches me about myself: And people say I'm selfish. Only my conscience is.
author: Vivek S.

description: Small hidden away, but definitely worth the find. Small selection but every selection was delicious. We got the Sake Sashimi, Sake Nigiri, Spicy Hamachi, John Collins and the Tempura roll. They do all raw except for the tempura which they put in a small oven and cook. Very fast, but every bite was amazing. I would come back and go to this hidden gem for sure!
author: Ninoldar N.

description:
My favorite sushi in the Bay Area. Fresh fish, fantastic quality, and excellent flavor combinations. 

While the rolls are always lovely, the best thing to order, in my opinion, is a variety of the nigiri. Their maguro and walu walu are excellent and their sake and hamachi will melt in your mouth!

Be warned, service is slow and erratic at best, and the space is small, hence the four stars. Seriously, a four person party is too large for them to usually accommodate. But regardless of the wait, this sushi is always worth it!
author: Talia B.

description:
Great find a couple of minutes' walk from Moscone and surrounding hotels. Fish super fresh, rolls creative and delicious.  Prices stunningly reasonable for this quality and this location. Extensive, creative cocktail and beer menu from the John Colins cocktail bar downstairs. 

Finding this place is a bit of an adventure (it's on the mezzanine level of the cocktail bar), and don't expect privacy or quiet. You'll be literally rubbing elbows with your neighbors at the sushi bar or communal tables, and the noise level is just south of "AC/DC show."  They don't take reservations, but the chefs' skill and tiny size of the place mean food comes out extremely quickly, so seats turn over fairly frequently.
author: David S.

description: Amazing Sushi and Fish.  Very small place upstairs from the bar. The wait is worth it.
author: Evan B.

description: It was so hard to find this place! Yu have to go trough a different bar and take the stairs. The fish was fresh but the maki weren't tasty. I'll probably have a nigiri next time.
author: Juliana A.

description: It's a really small and hard to find. It's in the "second" floor of a bar. It's great since you can also order cocktails and enjoy the music. The sushi here is great! But, since the place is small and only two cooks. You need to be patient. But, it's worth to wait. The price is in the top of $$, but not too expensive.
author: Qianren Z.

description: Great and super yummy sushi... my husband and I were surprised how good it was. The restaurant is kind of hidden, on the second floor of a lounge bar and the space is quite small. But definitely worth a try! I highly recommend!
author: Natalia W.

description: Overrated. At least don't go here at lunch time for the rolls. Menu is greatly limited during lunch time, the fish didn't seem too fresh, and you can see that they use small/minimal portions of fish. While it's not the worst I have had, it certainly seemed overpriced. The chairs they have here are also incredibly uncomfortable and it's not like the taste is worth it.
author: Boots S.

description:
SOLID sushi freshness and customer service that deserves 5 stars, but overall this place is a 3 star for now. Read why below.

Takoba is a super cute space that's located above a pretty sweet lounge! You can even order your cocktails at the bar and bring them with you to dinner. 

The sushi we ordered was very fresh, and was amazing quality. However, the menu was somewhat limited with only a handful of options for each category. Although the sushi was delicious, the rolls were not substantial and for the $11-14 price per roll, left us wanting. 

Minus stars for the limited seating, limited menu, and somewhat long wait.
author: Gabriella C.

description:
HOLY COOOOOOW! Yes, you will wait. But will this be the most awe inspiring sushi you've ever had? Yes. 

Once you're actually sat - it's pretty fast service. Must tries: Walu Nigiri (if you like this, try the Giant roll), the John Collins roll and SpecialXtra with blue bottled coffee sauce. The John Collins roll is much more subtle than the other two mentioned so if you're feeling adventurous go with the Giant roll.

Everything here is extremely good. It's worth the wait and it's a cool atmosphere.
author: Amber H.

description: The fish was fresh and great quality. Negi Hama was really really good. The venue is tiny and a bit hard to find also being above a bar it's pretty noisy but the neighborhood definitely needs a quality sushi place.
author: Bunny C.

description:
Needed a small dinner as I had flown in for the Dreamforce conference.  Noticed the high ratings on Yelp and went in.  

Space is very small, so it immediately feels authentic.  Only a couple dozen seats at most.  Menu was on the shorter end, but to be expected from a small place.  Had the Spicy Hamachi roll and the Giants roll. 

Spicy Hamachi - 9/10 - Very fresh, delicious, wasn't overly ricey.  Lots of content to the roll, and the flavors worked very well.  One of my favorites ever.

Giants - 10/10 - The best roll I've personally ever eaten.  Lots of personality to it, crispy deep fried rice bits that had a garlicky tint to it.  Unbelievable.  

Tried to go back during the duration of my trip, but twice wasn't open due to private events.  Strongly recommend to anybody who likes really good sushi.  Not exactly cheap, but wasn't overly expensive.  Service was good.  Only thing I'd change was that it seemed really hot in the place.  AC would have helped.
author: Dan W.

description:
Fresh amazing Shushi ! Highly recommended. I'm going back here, for sure!

When you get to the address, there is no sign outside, don't worry, you're in the right place, just go up to the second floor
author: Daniel B.

description:
Small  place and small menu but excellent and fresh sushi. And only sushi - no other options on this menu. Get there early and get on the list - there are maybe 20 seats in the whole place. Not good for groups. We enjoyed the game and drinks on the big screen in the bar downstairs and then dinner up. Bar has most of the sushi menu available if you just want to stay down to eat. If not - send someone to get on the list and they will call you when there are seats available. 

Had the Giant, Special Extra and John Collins. All were fabulous but especially loved the Special Extra.
author: Aimee S.

description: Stopped by this place on a late Saturday visiting SF. Is a cozy little spot and the sushi was imaginative, fresh and delicious. Would definitely go back her.
author: Richard N.

description:
Pretty good for the ingredients they use to put into the rolls and the taste of them. 

However for the price of the rolls, this would be more like a before-real-dinner kind of place to fill your sushi crave or impress your date before moving on to a real dinner that can fill you up. 

Also given it's at the mezzanine level of Jon Colins, seats are limited so groups larger than 3 are no recommended IMO.
author: Nina T.

description:
open for a year and only 18 reviews?

hands down. best sushi we've had this year. fresh, fine and delicious. the menu is very limited, but that's what makes them good. sashimi tasted so fresh and the rolls were amazing. $60 dinner for two and we actually left hungry because we had somewhere to be. could have easily spent well over $100 and be completely satisfied.

there are about 20 or so seats here - maybe less? i'm committed to coming here once a month until the entire city discovers it and ruins my life. by then, i'd hope they expand or take reservations.
author: Thao T.

description: You definitely want to check this place out! A true hidden gem in the city! The only downside is the super small area which makes the waiting time a bit longer. Sushi's are made to the perfection!
author: Rana K.

description: excellent service, fresh and interesting fish arrangements, interesting bar atmosphere....a great vibe in a hidden gem!
author: Janet K.

description: A wonderful find above the bar. Unusual combinations, extremely fresh and delectable sushi that leaves your tummy smiling!
author: Janet K.

description:
1)  good fish
2) interesting and creative and delicious rolls
3) waiters are friendly and upbeat 
4) its small and crowded
5) there aren't any backs on their chairs so you have to hunch in a bar stool
6) it is loud- so maybe not good for a first date- but definitely good for a third or fourth.
7) honestly the food is amazing and the drinks are strong and tasty so it's a definite win.


*Love this place.
author: Robert W.

description: I used to not eat raw fish, but this place changed me. The fish actually melts in your mouth, or at least it did on the night I went. The only complaint I'd have is that it can get kind of crowded - all the seating is on barstools. But it's a pretty cool space, tucked up upstairs inside John Collins lounge!
author: Grace Y.

description: Very cute and cozy sushi place - great food and amazing ambiance - just what we were looking for after spending the day at MOMA
author: Natalie L.

description: Went to Takoba with friends looking for a quick place to grab sushi and we were surprised by the atmosphere in a cool small location and quality of the sushi. It's a great experience and a bit harder to find since it's above a club that you have to walk into to get up to the restaurant...but really really worth it.
author: Daryl D.

description: Amazing sushi and fish quality. The John Collins Roll is fantastic. Along with the Poke Roll. I highly recommend it!
author: Shane O.

description:
I would have never guessed that there was a tiny sushi bar above a bar, but I'm glad we came upon it because it was delicious! We ordered 2 rolls - John Colins and the Takoba and they were both really the good! The rice was perfectly cooked and the fish was super fresh! The only downside is that the rolls are relatively small and the prices are relatively high. Quality over quantity! 

Overall, it's a cute area to enjoy really fresh and delicious sushi!
author: Sophia Y.

description:
If you like finding hip hole in the wall places - this is it. Impress your hipster date with knowing how to get inside through the John Collins restaurant entrance. You will have to wait.

Remember if you get takeout to ask for soy sauce!

Ordered: Tuna poke & spicy sake
Tuna poke is a roll, not sashimi like I was expecting, still very good, both rolls were delicious but I wish I had tried something more adventurous.
author: Stacey R.

description: This place was great! We came in around 7 on a Tuesday and waited about 15 minutes to get seated. It's a small place so the tables turn over fairly quickly; just don't come with a huge party or anything. The rolls are all unique and the fish is FRESH! I'd recommend a nigiri or sashimi order first so you can experience this freshness in all its glory. Of the four rolls we got, I really enjoyed the Spicy Hamachi and the Oban. The service was also great. Wonderful experience all around!
author: Brittany L.

description: THis is a strange tiny sushi bar up the stairs inside the bar Jon Collins.  The sushi is tasty, the staff is friendly.  But their menu is very limited, basically same 6 or so ingredients assorted into rolls, nigiri, sashimi.  It's good but very limited. I'd recommend, but be aware it's not a broad offering.
author: gary g.

description:
I've been to Takoba a number of times for drinks and sushi dinner with friends after work. I particularly love sitting upstairs at the sushi bar where you can see the bar downstairs fill up and come to life. They also have a huge projector downstairs where they showcase calming beach scene videos, which I think is a really fun touch. Overall, the atmosphere is awesome for a casual drink to catch up with friends or to mingle with new people. The music is never too loud so you can actually hold a conversation during HH. 

In terms of drinks, they offer a nice cocktail menu, my personal favorite is the John Colins cocktail. I've also sampled a few of their red wines and have been very pleased. The bar and wait staff are are friendly and super helpful while the prices are affordable. 

I go mostly for their sushi, they just opened up the sushi bar upstairs a few months ago and they are always refining the menu. If you like sushi, they have a roll for you. I've gone and had a hand roll as a snack if I was planning on going to dinner later and I've also spent a few hours upstairs to try several rolls on the menu for a full dinner. This is also a great bar to catch the game downstairs. Highly recommend.
author: Vivienne G.

description:
This place is literally a hole in the wall!

The location of this place is INSIDE another bar. The portions for the sushi is not that big, but none the less the sushi taste fresh and amazing. Their drinks are also amazing. You definitely taste the alcohol. lol
author: Pj A.

description: The Chirashi bowl was extremely small. I always try that when I go to a nice Japanese restaurant. Even when I am in Japan, I try Chirashi bowl. We waited an hour to get seated upstairs. It is extremely small. You can always order a limited selection of sushi (I am not sure how limited it becomes). Next time I will just order from downstairs and not wait. The sushi was fresh but I do expect that for the price I pay. I just wish they give you a couple of more pieces.
author: Jeeyoung K.

description: Takoba was such a pleasant surprise. It's easy to miss since their store front is actually a lounge called John Collins. To get to the restaurant itself, you'll have to go up the stairs to your left. The food was so good. Great portions. The fish was so fresh and their rolls were amazing. They have about 8-10 selections and all the different combinations sounded amazing. We ended up ordering 5 rolls and a chef selection assortment of sashimi just between 3 girls. We ordered 3 initially - john collins, spicy hamachi, and a 3rd rill that I cant remember. It was so good we put in an order for 2 more rolls - not because we weren't full but because we couldn't stop. The 2 additional rolls we ordered were midori and the takoba. Haven't written a review in awhile but couldn't live with myself if I didn't write one so ppl can know about this place. I took away 1 star cuz seating was limited so when they get busy the wait can get a bit long.
author: Christine C.

description: Food was good - once we finished eating we were asked "are you all ready to go? We need this space". Last time I'll be here, completely unacceptable thing to say to someone who just spent $100
author: Drew S.

description: Had a great time and the sushi was delicious. Some of the best salmon I've ever had. Very beautiful and hip place as well
author: Jimmy G.

description: Service and everything was fine-- although do note that since this restaurant is in a bar you will need to be 21 or over. The sushi was very... plain. The fish was very fresh and the ingredients seemed good, but I found the flavor to be lacking. The cocktails were much better than the actual food haha.
author: Nick E.

description: On the pricey side but definitely worth the price - the rolls I had were the best I have ever had anywhere! Didn't even need soy sauce. It's pretty hard to find, it's up the stairs in a bar. Great little corner for a catch-up with friends or a quick treat for yourself.
author: Samantha S.

description: Wow this place was expensive, seating was cramped, portions were small and service was woefully slow. I can't believe it was so highly rated. The only reason it even got one star was because the quality of the food was pretty decent.
author: Fabian M.

description:
Very good sushi. Great prices

Second floor of a bar --- not as an odd as it sounds

Worth a try!!!
author: Justin R.

description: I've tried everything in this sushi place, and not a single piece of sushi let me down! This is the best sushi restaurant I've ever been in SF. Can't live without it!
author: Dingding Sherry W.

description: I loved this place. They have fresh quality of sushi rolls. It was all decently fresh and delicious. Quite wide menu tho
author: Perla S.

description: The perfect post-work happy hour slash sushi combo. Good drinks downstairs and surprisingly tasty (not just fresh but tasty) nigiri and sashimi. Rolls were crowd pleasers in my group of engineers, as was my dad bod jelly roll.
author: Stephen H.

description: Small menu but fresh fish cut in big hunks, Hawaiian style!  Have dined there 4-5x and it never disappoints.  Great bar menu from downstairs and friendly staff.
author: Pueo K.

description: i can't wait to come back to Takoba :). Takoba is easy to miss because they don't actually have a storefront sign. you have to enter the John Collins bar and make a quick left to find the slim set of stairs that lead to max 20 person dining space. i went with a girlfriend on a Friday night and the wait was about an hour. time was easy to kill because of Jim Collins and the live DJ downstairs, and they texted us when our table was ready so we wouldn't've been too worried about walking elsewhere to kill time. we got the namesake roll and it was delicious- tuna quality was 100.
author: Meryam B.

description:
In town for business and in need of a quick bite, I stopped in to Takoba and had a really good meal. It's tiny, with only about 20 seats inside. Clearly high quality fish, especially at really reasonable prices. I had:
-Miso soup - better than the average miso soup with quality tofu and mushrooms in it.
-tuna poké roll - interesting presentation here, basically an avocado roll with really good portions of chunks of season tuna on top (the pieces are sideways on the plate to accommodate more fish per piece). 
-John Colins roll - I was intrigued by the tequila-cured salmon in this one. While I didn't really taste the tequila, it was still solid and came with a great aioli on top. 

Overall, very good meal at Takoba. I'd definitely recommend for a quick bite or casual date anytime.
author: Daniel D.

description: Take-out order ready at the time stated; enjoyed excellent sushi in my hotel room. TheTakoba roll was most interesting, though I'm not usually a fan of the elaborate rolls.  Selection of other sushi was excellent.
author: John L.

description: This is the first negative review I've ever written, but we were greatly disappointed in this place. We were a party of four and when we put our name on the wait list they told us no problem it is a 45 minute wait. One hour and fifteen minutes later we went up to check on how much longer it would be. At that point we found out that they had seated SIX parties of two before us. They were extremely rude and said parties of four are hard to seat. They tried to squeeze us at the end of a table where two people were intended to sit. We ended up leaving without ordering because the servers were so rude. It would have been much appreciated if they just told us from the beginning that parties of four cannot be accommodated instead of wasting an hour and a half of our night. Moral of the story- if you are more than a party of two, DO NOT GO HERE!!
author: Kimiya M.

description: wow this place is good! busy during happy hour but definitely worth it, fish is fresh and cuts are beautiful to the eyes and well as the tummy.  Definitely a hidden gem worth finding.
author: howard c.

description: IN LOVE! I live in the neighborhood & discovered this gem recently. Its an absolute secret and you must walk up a tiny hidden staircase - think Harry Potter...small, delicious, great service & above a bar with fantastic music.
author: Charlotte J.

description:
Fun spot to grab good sushi before heading out to drink or get into mischief. Situated upstairs, it has a cool window bar that looks out over the alley. Menu is simple, and fresh. Sadly, the two items I wanted were not available. Uni and Saba. 
Still great sushi. Not high brow or cheesy. John Collins bar down stairs was packed after I finished. Very popular Friday night watering hole.
author: Jacob C.

description: Great sushi. We popped in on a Thursday night before a comedy show thanks to Yelp. There was a half hour wait, but we were also told we could sit downstairs and order off their limited menu. So that's what we did. Had some Saki and some rolls, the typical rolls you get at most places however the fish was fresh and rolled perfectly. Now if I could only teach Chrissy how to use chopsticks correctly.
author: Andrew Q.

description: OMGosh that was so yummy. If you're looking for volume, go somewhere else.  If however you're wanting quality sushi, you won't be disappointed. Probably some of the best sushi I've ever had (and I lived in Japan 5 years). If you find this "hidden nugget of gold", you'll feel that you've struck it rich! Till next time....
author: Dennis H.

description:
Very cozy and fancy place. Service was a little slow but they were packed so it was understandable. The rolls are delicious, I especially enjoyed the tequila soaked salmon.
Quite pricy, however. Would recommend if you're looking for something professional and legit, not when you're starving.
author: Jenny L.

description: Awesome sushi!  FRESH and tasty.  The Special Xtra might have been the best roll I've ever had. Sat in bar downstairs had drinks and sushi, great place.
author: Mark N.

description:
My review is a few months old.  Both the service and food were exemplary.  I am with Vivek though, I really didn't want to write this review but they deserve their stars.

Intimate atmosphere, exotic food, awesome drinks from John Colins, I highly recommend that you come here to "close a deal"...I did.
author: Jeff J.

description: This hidden spot is actually pretty good! The restaurant is on the second floor overlooking a bar, which is an interesting concept. I didn't expect the sushi to be that fresh, but I was pleasantly surprised - overall, a good place in FiDi if you're looking for a quick sushi fix.
author: Rebecca W.

description: I will state the positive first, the staff is awesome, and the fish they have is very good. I also like that they let you call in and put your name on the list, very uncommon for sushi bars. 3 stars because they have very little selection. When I am traveling, like I am now, I want a good sushi bar with a lot of selection, especially traditional selections, and options for me to order some custom things. This was not an option here, they did not want to hear about anything custom. They only have a half a dozen fish options on the menu. And no uni. That is the most traditional and best sushi option for any true sushi eater.
author: Jeff H.

description: Excellent little find!!  Came here right at 5pm, got great seats.  We literally tried all of the rolls between 4 of us!  Great atmosphere, the service was spectacular.  I loved the poke rolls, but my favorite was the tempura shrimp...so gooood!!  I'm hungry!! =)
author: Chet T.

description: I got their takoba roll and the salmon avocado roll --  amazing dinner decision! I didn't think I was that hungry but it's all gone. The wait time was a little long for my liking (over an hour) but considering its election night, I ordered at prime dinner time, and the place is pretty small, I excepted it. I couldn't find the entrance (it's my first night in SF) but they were super helpful on the phone and my order was ready and waiting for me even though I arrived earlier than expected.
author: Ashley P.

description: The best shushi I've ever had in the US!!! Nice place, space is a little limited.
author: Chih-Wei C.

description: Hard to find as it is in a loft above a bar. Once you get there it's a small space with a very limited menu. The sushi is fresh and delicious - well worth the search. No hot sake, but access to the full bar menu downstairs.
author: Delilah B.

description: We waited for over an hour before they told us that tables of 4 were difficult to sit. They say 6 parties of 2 that came after us and had people's purses and jackets taking up an extra spot. Horrible place.
author: Monica G.

description: I really like the pasta here, super good! Especially the chicken tikka masala hmmm yummyy!
author: Rosario H.

description:
Are you in Soma looking for some fresh sushi and happy hour?  I recommend Takoba.  This restaurant is part of the bar John Collins which to me is quite the hidden gem.  The cocktail servers will take care of your drink orders while the sushi servers will take your food orders.  The sushi is delicious and fresh.  There is a hidden upstairs where the actual sushi bar is, but venture up because the seating area upstairs is shiek and intimate.  Try the John Collins roll the salmon is delish.  The only downside to me- which I hope is something the management will change sooner rather than later, is that the food and drinks are not linked so drinks have to be ordered at the bar or with a different server.  BUT I would still say pop in for a game after work and check this place out.

P.S. there is a parking garage across the street
author: Gabbi d.

description: The place is quite small and it offers interesting flavors. Some sushi tastes a bit ordinary and overprice. But they have their own unique sushi that is good.
author: Alvin Z.

description:
The sushi was really delicious - what we ordered had good spice and crunch to it, and the fish was nice and fresh. We did have to wait about half an hour, though. After we put our name on the list, we went down to the bar downstairs, but after two minutes at the bar, we realized we couldn't handle it because it was so noisy. We went around the corner to House of Shields for a drink instead. 
All in all, despite the fact that it really was like eating sushi in a club thanks to the noise and music downstairs, the sushi itself made up for it.
author: Rowan H.

description:
Good, cheap nigiri and maki rolls in a neat little space above the John Collins bar. They have a succinct little menu which takes some liberties and breaks from the norm of traditional sushi fare - Tequila infused salmon, creamy and savory garnish on the 'Takoba' roll and a really unique spicy tuna mixture were details that stood out in my order. It's cool and interesting. The fish was of a pretty high quality and the chef we spoke to was very knowledgable and seemed passionate about her craft.

On the down side, it seems like they're still "figuring stuff out" as far as service goes - the seating was a little tight and the servers were nice but seemed a little green. Also, it may be the way the acoustics/walls are in there, but the party at the communal table behind us sounded REALLY obnoxiously loud. Not the restaurant's fault, but worth noting if you're trying to go in there for a conversation during evening hours when there are more people in the space.
author: Narek A.

description: Love this place.  I always order at the bar to avoid the wait.  Great sushi!
author: Christiana L.

description: Definitely a hidden spot but pretty good sushi. I ordered online for a pick up and it was ready right on time despite being busy. Spicy Tuna was good as was the Takoba speciality roll. Servers were definitely busy polite. Place probably seats 15 people max.
author: Bryan M.

description: Excelllent service and food! Servers are very friendly and warm, sushi is high quality and delicious!
author: Sy D.

description: Probably the best quality for the price anywhere in SOMA. 'Hidden' right above John Collins, there's very limited seating in the actual restaurant. However, you can order from SF downstairs in the bar (limited menu though). Always delicious and the fish is so fresh.
author: Teresa J.

description: Great little whole in the wall restaurant with a small but fascinating menu. Filled with enticing options and tons of variety. I tried the John Collin's roll which great. Friends ordered the Takabo and the Special Xtra, which were both very good, but I preferred mine. Also ordered a California hand roll, which was by far the best hand roll I've ever had. Prices are reasonable and it's a cozy environment so go check it out.
author: Jeremiah M.

description: This place is small, but it's worth it! They use different ingredients in their sushi rolls, you won't find these at your average sushi joints. Nice little place to stop by after a movie or a late night at work!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Not as intuitive to find it as it is a small place on the second floor of the John Collins bar. Food is fantastic! Ambience is awesome and the service was just great!!!

Menu is simple, very affordable and of great quality. I recommend the John Collins roll. I highly recommend it... and I will be back!
author: Alessandro M.

description:
Great little sushi place in SoMA - and it somehow makes it better that this place is actually inside the Joh Collins bar. At first, this makes it hard to find but the seating and ambiance are fun once you get inside. 

There are few choices on the menu but we loved everything we tried! Plus, it doesn't hurt to have the ability to order cocktails while you're nomming down on some fresh fish.
author: Rashmi J.

description: Mouth climax :) sushis were delicious. I had John Collins (amazing) and Takoba rolls.
author: Ilona N.

description: Got here early on a Thursday (before 6) decided to get some sushi before checking out the Kubrick exhibit. Excellent seats overlooking Minna St. Drinks came up from the bar downstairs, all the cocktails were great, beer was cold. Sushi was perfect. Chef's nigiri sampler had salmon,tuna,eel, a really nice Hawaiian sea bass and another - all of it was excellent, fresh, firm and prefect temperature. We also had a roll that had shrimp tempura inside with salmon on top (i can't remember the name) but the tempura was just excellent - perfectly crispy (not soggy like a lot of places that seem to use older tempura) - the service was really nice and it was a very enjoyable evening. We will definitely be coming back for more!
author: Wesley W.

description: Came here while away at work and experienced one of the best rolls of my life. The spicy hamachi was incredible. Wish I could get the same at home. It's small and definitely worth arriving early so you can enjoy the full menu upstairs. Glad I found this tiny gem!
author: Jackie T.

description: Great service, very fresh and tasty rolls, above a swanky bar- a winning combo. Truly a hidden gem in SoMa...a must try. Wednesday nights have all day Happy Hour, while playing classic tunes
author: Adam J.

description:
everything about this place is so right on. 
charming and delicious... 
perfect little "secret" ... my dinner companion and I were more than pleased.... 
can't wait to go back...
author: Nik N.

description: A Japanese sushi bar with very interesting location. The portion of maki is smaller than I expected but still good.
author: Yow-Bang W.

description: My friends and I stumbled upon this tiny place, and were so pleased we did! It's the second floor of a bar and super intimate. Can only fit about 15-20 people. We had a 30 minute wait so walked down the stairs and got a drink from the bar there. Worth the wait! Small menu but each roll was delicious. Friendly staff as well. I recommend! A cute find in SF.
author: Alyssa C.

description: Fresh. Unique. Fragrant. The fish was so fresh. The rolls were so unique and full of flavor. Perfect flavor a that made your mouth water. We Ate double the amount of sushi we'd normally eat. It was that good!
author: Mark C.

description: Fantastic sushi and service, in a very small space above the main bar area of John Collins. Coming from DC, I'm not used to world class sushi, but the walu nigiri I had was some of the best sushi I've ever eaten in my life. I remarked to the sushi chef as much (I think he might have been the owner, Mark), and he gave me a free yellowtail (hamachi) nigiri, which was also excellent. Their sushi rolls are creative; not things you'd typically find elsewhere, and enjoyable. They had a great local pilsner on tap, and service was prompt and and frequent, though it helped that I was sitting at the sushi counter directly behind the cash register. So it can be a little cramped, but the food, drinks, and service are top notch.
author: Stephen K.

description: Oh my goodness. This place is delicious!!! Really great quality sushi ad very very tasty!!! We loved the Walu nigiri, John Colins roll, Giants roll, Tuna Poke roll. Highly recommend.
author: Yvette M.

description: Absolutely delicious. This place is a hidden gem for sure. All the rolls on the menu are excellent and even the miso soup is bomb.
author: Bryan L.

description: I love the sushi at Takoba! I think I've tried all of their hand rolls and sushi rolls by now and they're all simply delicious. The John Colins roll is probably my favorite, who would've thought that salmon marinated in tequila would taste so amazing?! The Chef here is quite innovative and his food definitely reflects that. To add, it's in a great location inside John Colins Lounge and other great bar/lounges within walking distance. I keep coming back for more so I highly recommend it!
author: Nita C.

description: Great Sushi and Service ! Small Sushi Bar but you can order downstairs in the larger John Collins which is a very inviting place to consume alcohol
author: John B.

description: The full bar is located on the first floor, thankfully the noise level is not too outrageous.  The restaurant is on the second floor, seats maybe 30 ppl max?  We decided to order our food from the bar instead since it was a bit stuffy up there.  Menu is kind of small, but the rolls are delicious and sashimi is fresh.  The ambiance is cool, a nice hang out place after work no doubt!
author: Vicky H.

description: awesome spot! almost missed it because it's upstairs in john collins, which is also an awesome bar :)
author: Maxine E.

description: Such fresh sushi! Tiny hole in the wall located in the upstairs of John Collins bar. Menu is short as well, but the fish is delicious and the rolls inventive and tasty. Obsessed!
author: Alison W.

description: Great fresh fish! The place is very small so come early! Though they have a bar you should go through to find this place, so it's not a problem to wait. I had a Hemingway at the bar and it was spectacular! Try chef's choice sashimi and you won't regret.
author: Julia O.

description: The sushi restaurant is above a bar (John Collins Lounge) and reasonably priced. I sat at the sushi bar and enjoyed the ambience and the overall experience. The fish was fresh, tender and tasty. I would go back.
author: R M.

description: Hidden germ. Very decent sushi with a surprisingly fair price. The four most popular rolls on the pictures are very good, and we like the unagi one the most
author: Jennifer S.

description: Reading the reviews I understood it was a hole in the wall.. what I didn't realize it was LITERALLY hidden from plain sight!!! If anything I felt lucky enough to have stumbled upon this place.. IT IS THE DEFINITION OF A HIDDEN GEM!!!! Very small and intimate. Great small little menu full of amazingness! My boyfriend were able to sit at the bar facing the street.. which had a perfect view of a restaurants kitchen, so that another plus. The fish tasted soo yummy, and fresh.. unlike any affordable sushi place I have ever been too before!!
author: Caitlin A.

description: Closed on Mondays! Did t know until we walked from Westfield SF Mall to the restaurant. Bummer!
author: Delores M.

description: Best sushi place ever!! I really like this one because its small and cozy..we seat next to the window and it was very nice..order misu soup that was grate and 7 diffrent sushi and they all was perfect.. drink some cocktails that was good too.. the workers are super nice!! I like that its like a "secret" spot and not too fancy and  full of people , and so is the price..its really worth every penny!! Will recommend :)
author: Violet O.

description: The sushi is decent. Nothing too crazy just salmon, crab, and tuna options for fish. My mojito was okay and my fiance wanted a specific whiskey and they didn't have it so they brought out an alternative which was comparable. I would come back but not my first choice for sushi.
author: Julianne C.

description:
The food here and the service is amazing!!  Thats the upside. . . the downside is it's VERY VERY small.  I would guess there are only about 18 total seats so be ready to come and put your name down and then enjoy a drink downstairs.  On the other hand, when we arrived with a group of 3, the staff helped rearrange other parties already seated to help squeeze us in.  They certainly didnt have to but it was greatly appreciated. 

Food wise, we tried 3 rolls and the chef's sashimi choice.  Everything was super fresh and absolutely delicious . . . and VERY reasonably priced.  One of the best sushi places I've been to in awhile.  

Cannot wait to go back
author: C W.

description: Small place with heavenly delicious pieces !
author: Gzde C.

description: Small little place. Excellent service. Better than average sushi rolls with unexpected combinations and flavors.
author: Geoff S.

description:
This is a tiny little place inside the John Colins bar. The space is really cool - a kind of balcony overlooking the bar's main floor. The sushi is great, food is prepared fast, and prices are (for sushi of this quality, at least) pretty reasonable.

The only reason this isn't five stars is the service - when I was there, a new waitress was in training who, while competent generally, didn't have good enough English comprehension skills to pick out anything we said in that (very noisy - it's upstairs from a crowded bar!) environment. They're also still working some things out organizationally - the menu seemed a bit out of date compared to what they were actually serving, since the place is so new and they're still deciding what mix works.
author: Asa Z.

description:
Exceptional in every way.  A very memorable meal.

As a non-resident, I don't have the reservations expressed here about sharing a stealth sushi place, but I understand the sentiment.  If I lived here, I might eat here all the time and never tell anyone about it.

Service and food were excellent - we had some hamachi sashimi and about half of the maki menu, of which the Mina was the standout.  The quality of the fish was excellent, and it was never upstaged by a sauce.  I like the small menu, it seems like it represents the ethos of doing a few things well, rather than many things mediocre.  

My only criticisms are the size of the restaurant - it was a little cramped.  Not really negative, but the miso soup was exactly like every other bowl of miso soup I have ever had.  While we are on the subject, why does miso soup not taste like miso?  Not as exceptional as the rest of the meal is about as critical as I can get about it.  Go for the sushi, not for the soup.  Unless you want standard miso soup.  

In a fair world, their talent would be shared with the sushi-loving world, and they would reap the success they deserve - this is the reason for my review.  Hopefully their success can propel them into a bigger space.
author: Adam K.

description: Delicious rolls. We pretty much tried one of everything and they were all good! There isn't much seating upstairs but it was nice being one of the only customers. You can also order sushi from downstairs at the bar. Overall it was a good experience and I will return the next time I visit sf.
author: Allison S.

description: Amazing seafood for low prices.  Best sushi I've had in years.
author: Cody G.

description: The sushi was great! very fresh and creative. The waitresses was very sweet and attentive. The only thing I would comment on is that it was a bit hard to find because I didn't see a sign outside. Its on the second floor of a bar. My party really enjoyed it and I recommend it!
author: Olivia R.

description: This place is fantastic--definitely a hidden gem as has been said on many of the reviews. The rolls were amazing and the vibe/ambiance was awesome, sitting at the window bar overlooking Minna street. I love that the menu explicitly states where each fish came from, because sustainability is so important when consuming fish. The fish was some of the most fresh I have had yet in San Francisco. The one issue was that the waitstaff seemed very confused and could not answer questions such as "which roll is better/which is your favorite" or give good cocktail recommendations. I will definitely be returning, and I am hoping that my server will be able to give me better recommendations next time.
author: Chloe A.

description: Simply disappointing. The first evening we had (GREAT) sushi in Sanraku and wanted to replicate great experience in some other comparable sushi bar. So I trusted these high ratings (4.5!) for this place. I am not sure how they managed to get such high ratings, but the quality of sushi was 2/2.5 at best. Moreover, some ingredients did not seem to be fresh.
author: Denys P.

description: Almost like a pop-up sushi bar, located in an upper niche/balcony of John Collins bar. Points for the hidden location, makes the experience more exciting! It wasn't super busy - no wait. Service was average. We each ordered a cocktail (moscow mule and dirty martini) and 3 rolls (2 makis, 1 Giants). The server was very quick to bring us water and take our order but after delivering the moscow mule without my martini, she was mia. 15 minutes later another girl comes over and asks if i had a martini. i told her i was still waiting. several minutes after that, the server comes back and it'll be a moment. i'm understanding still...i was in service for a decade, but this was pushing it. minutes after that, my martini shows up and she apologized saying they needed to go in teh back to get more of the gin. well, clever bartender, Venus is $9 and low and behold, so is Tanqueray. substitute! or, typically bartenders up it one especially if they make the guest wait a while. the wait for the food was a bit too much, especially considering the menu is very simply (a handle of makis, only a few nigiri selections and a few basic rolls). Seemed like fresh fish thankfully. The server shied away from us after all the wait though, which isn't always a good thing. She cleared the plate very quickly when we were done (though points for bringing me extra ginger!) and then we were awkwardly waiting for another 15 min with only a sip of a drink left for the bill. Though a dollar or 2 less than some sushi places in the same area, I still feel that for the amount and quality and wait, it wasn't really worth it. This place has potential, but really needs to reign it all in. OK experience overall.
author: Zara S.

description: This restaurant is only for 21+ so don't waste your time here if you are not. We came here at 6 pm and they were already requesting ids and didn't let us even order sushi to go.
author: Xitlaly E.

description: I don't really see how this place deserves such high reviews. While the servers were really nice, the food took quite some time to be served and was of average quality and small servings. The restaurant is very small, meaning a limited menu, although this is not necessarily a bad thing. However, the ambiance was somewhat noisy due to the bar downstairs, and the high stools are a little uncomfortable.
author: Albert H.

description: Stumbled across this awesome sushi place hidden in a nice alley in SoMa. Great, high quality sushi that is made right near you. Great drinks because there is a full bar downstairs. And neat, cozy dining area. Be careful if you are having a confidential business meeting as you will be seated elbow to elbow next to fellow tech folks.
author: Quinn S.

description: This was amazing. we tried a few different rolls and sashimi and everything was great. The fish was really fresh and the rolls had really great ingredient combinations. 10/10 A+
author: Elizabeth Y.

description: I will certainly be returning to Takoba in the near future. A tiny restaurant hidden on the upper level of John Collins bar, Takoba has an interesting vibe. The kitchen overlooks the bar and, at least during my visit, hip hop music quietly played in the background. The sushi was great but their menu, like the restaurant itself, is rather small. I had the Takoba roll and Unagi nigirizushi - both of which were delicious. I would have given a 5 star review, however the rolls were a little pricier than I anticipated.
author: Jay T.

description: Nothing short of amazing. Friendly service and the food was phenomenal. Like, better than any high priced fancy LA sushi we've ever had, better than Nobu by a mile better than sushi roku. Crazy fresh ingredients, really creative preparation. But yea a little small and a little hard to find which only makes it more interesting.
author: jen h.

description: This is quite possibly the best nigiri in San Francisco. And I like everyone who works here. I usually come here every Wednesday.
author: Douglas W.

description: Delicious sushi and great drinks menu. You can actually order the sushi anywhere in the bar, so you don't have to wait for a seat in the cute (but small) restaurant portion. The perfect place to grab after work dinner and drinks.
author: Leah S.

description: Excellent sushi, in a secret spot above a bar. Very high quality fish!!! Must try for sushi lovers in SF. Get the Giants!
author: Joe A.

description: Great sushi at a great price, it can't beat, lucky it's still a hidden gem and easy to get in. The quality of the fish is as good or better than most sushi restaurants to half the price.
author: Hawaii t.

description: Found this little spot through yelp as I was staying in the Financial District and wanted to walk around a bit. As other have noted it's within a bar and then you have to go upstairs, and it's this cozy little spot - probably seats no more than 20. I placed my order for pickup, but it reminded me of dinner at a friends house. The staff were so nice. I had to wait a few extra minutes for part of my order, which I was totally fine with since I had no place to be. But they were extra accommodating, and even provided me a few pieces of nigiri on the house. totally unexpected and unnecessary - but great service nonetheless. The food - spot on. I ordered the miso soup, the John Colin's and the Special Xtra and then the salmon nigiri. The John Colin's was spicy but AWESOME. The piece just melts in your mouth. The Special Xtra was really good as well. I love how fresh everything tasted. And the rice, was on point. Hate when rolls are falling apart or are too sticky. Will definitely be back when I'm in the area!
author: Colette A.
